The previous contradictions within the self-justification of the Sibyl system and the order it has imposed on the whole society have been eliminated. It is this point that differentiates the show from many other dystopian works, for there are no dictator, no deliberate oppression, and no obvious sacrifice of a group of people for the interest of another group of people. The law and order developed by this fictional world, though cold-blooded, sometimes even terrifying, is able to realise a form of justice in the sense that everyone is equal in front of the law and literally no exceptions can be permitted. And for most of the people who live in that society under the control of such order, there is more or less a happy life awaiting. As one time the heroin Tsunemori imagined her old friend, who were killed in the first season’s show, asking her in self-doubt that if she had lived a happy life when she was alive, though she was a little bit lazy, not clever, had limited choices in life and no further aim or ambition, the answer was a definite “Yes". 


At the same time, this ending is quite disturbing. As viewers, we have to ask this question after we finishing watching this special show: is this a society that we would accept? If not, what will be the main reason to reject it, when it can be self-justified intellectually and seemingly morally? Intuitively, we would say no to it. It seems that, at first glance, it is not a desirable society compared with the one in which we are living. But we cannot instantly think of a very valid rejection when we have considered all aspects of its self-justification. Moreover, if we neglect various bloody and violent scenes that highlighted in the show (which means that the real practice of such socio-political order in an imaginable way might be much more mild than what we have witnessed), and if we just examine the Sybil system in the show’s own settings (that this is a chaotic world after a series of wars and Japan with the “equipment” of the Sybil system is one of the few regions that could keep a peaceful order), we may have fewer reasons to reject it. 


Firstly, one ambiguity points to the question that is this society a genuine dystopia or not? Evidently, it is not a utopia since initially it has not been conceived as a society better than us. But its dystopian features are also not very distinctive compared with other works in a similar strand. On the one hand, it has already been motioned that this society seems to be morally self-consistent. On the other hand, it also has a moderate and practical ultimate aim, which is to keep a peaceful and ordinary domestic social order. Many other dystopian worlds, in contrast, would have a much more ambitious purpose like improvement of the mankind or transforming the way of human life through new technologies. They try to display a way of life that apparently not better, but most of the time an alternative one compared to what we already have. From this perspective, the Sybil system, which no doubt contains high degree of technology, is just trying to provides an old-form way of life which is not very distinctive from which we are familiar with, and a practical solution within a chaotic world, although inevitably under some new conditions and limitations. So the central question still lies on what grounds we could consider the society as a dystopia and fully reject it as a practical response to a chaotic social order. 


Indeed, we could easily identify a major problem of this society that makes us feel morally unacceptable. After all, its peaceful order is based on a systematic and sometimes dogmatic exclusion of a group of people in this society. It is not a fair order because the excluded are deprived of all the rights to live a normal life, though with a chance to regain the opportunities if one recovers from the “muddy” psycho-pass state. If someone could be put into the isolation centres just because of his or her temporary mental state, it is unfair to those who naturally carry a high psycho-pass disposition or fall into a condition that would increase psycho-pass only by chance. Actually this unfairness of the Sybil system society might be the main reason why it feels intuitively unacceptable according to our modern moral standards. Yet, such a society can hardly be called a dystopian one. Even if we do not borrow Foucault’s criticism on the modern human society that has reflected a quite similar picture of systematically excluding people with certain “defects” that are considered deviant from the normal society, we could still see a multitude of similar cases that have appeared in the human history. Exclusions based on gender, ethnic groups, races, to name but a few, are all not unfamiliar in our history, and we could still witness such phenomena in our daily lives. Hence, in this aspect, the Sybil system society is not an unfair dystopian world that possesses greater evil than that of us. And it is also imaginable that through the possible improvements and designs of the Psycho-pass measurement, the standards for the law enforcement, and the recovering facilities and methods, etc., when technology develops and the Sybil system expands, the formerly explicit exclusions will become more implicit and less offensive. Such changes will naturally come into beings if this society continues to develop, since it coincides with Sybil system’s own logic that its ultimate aim is to keep a peaceful order. There are no reasons for it not to implement such measures if they could reduce dissatisfactions and further harmonise the society. 


Furthermore, when we look back to the major invention of this science fiction, and also which would seems to be the symbolic dystopian feature, the constitution of the Sybil system, we might find it less alienated than we initially feel. One way it could justify itself is that actually it is not a form of artificial intelligence that controls the human society, but pure human intelligence with the support of the highly developed biotechnology. In this sense, although quite different from our common sense, it still can be counted as a form of self-government of human beings, not government by machines or high-level AI like in many other dystopian works. An instant response to this system, apart from a natural antipathy to such a human minds combination, would claim that it is still a system that subjected to authoritative and maybe arbitrary decisions of some people, and it cannot breed true justice if a society’s fate is determined by a number of outliers. But this problem has been solved after the collective psycho-pass measurement was adopted. The outliers are also included in the whole system and are subjected to the law made by them. And based on the settings of the first season of the show, the Sybil system can continue absorb individuals with criminally asymptomatic feature or other distinctive features to improve its diversity. Based on the setting of the show’s ending, the system can renew itself and replace the old members with newcomers from the society. Under such circumstances, the society and its judges are closely interlocked as a fate-sharing community. They are not isolated as an authoritative ruler and the rest who are ruled any more. To use a literally fitting but meaningfully a slight different analogy, the Sybil system can even be seen as "a government of the people, by the people, for the people”. Only the second “people” here does not indicate every member of the society, instead they are “elites” who naturally possess certain features. So in the end it is more like the perfect form of “philosopher kings government” than a popular control democracy. Nevertheless, this does not necessarily make the Psycho-pass society a dystopia. 



II. Slave, or Man As His Own Master?


What will, then, be the reason for us to consider this society as a dystopia and fully reject it? How should we solve this “puzzle” if the above accounts are not convincing enough to characterise the society in Psycho-pass as a dystopia? In fact the show does give us a clue to reflect on this question if we try to examine its main characters. Although in the first place it was the genius rebel Makishima who is Criminally Asymptomatic in the show’s first season renouncing this system and it was the main male character Kōgami who had to go into exile after he defied the will of the Sybil system and lynched Makishima, and even if the rebel Kamui in the end of the second season became satisfied with the solution to incorporate Sybil system itself into the psycho-pass system and accepted his death peacefully, it is the heroin, Tsunemori, who still firmly rejected the legitimacy of the system after it has evolved into a more just form. Before joining the police department, she was an innocent and outstanding graduate who lived a normal life, had close friends, and followed the instructions of the Sybil system as others did and achieved the highest score in the capability assessment test. So, what changed her views towards the whole system after two years experience as a law enforcement agent? What is the source of the influence? Has her position in the system also changed after all these stories? 


If we want to explore the reason behind her firm rejection, we need to place ourselves in this society, and to examine it inside from Tsunemori's point of view and try to feel what she feels. Since she naturally possesses a very low degree of psycho-pass coefficient and a high capability according to the standards set by the Sibyl system, Tsunemori is a pure beneficiary of this society. Yet in the last scenes, we saw a lonely figure who turned her back towards the system and finished a cigarette by herself in her department, a habit that she acquired after Kōgami’s leaving, and the cigarette’s brand Kōgami’s favourite. Though she is and will be determined, she is alone and dissatisfied as well. The dissatisfaction comes from her not agreeing with the Sybil system and the effect that the imposed order has caused to the society, it also comes from the fact that starting from this point, she has no companions, no friends, and does not belong to the both sides of the society. She is not a member of the majority anymore, and this detachment process started from the moment she became a police working for the Sybil system, and completed after her former close friend was killed and she witnessed the real constitution of the system. Nor she is a member working for the system as instructed anymore, and since she rejected the offer to be absorbed into the Sybil system, she is not a member within them as well. Thus it becomes that she does not belong to this whole community that interlocked by the system and the society. She is not within the One and hence she is Another One, an outlier, like those who rebelled and those who were exiled. She becomes self-determined, acting only upon her own will, and here exactly lies all the loneliness. 


It is interesting that in an interview the writer of the first season’s script were asked about Tsunemori’s thought and hope, he replied that “Tsunemori’s justice is the spirit of democracy, therefore she is not satisfied with Sybil system’s obscurantism. She thinks that the procedures have their values even if they do not have concrete meanings.” But is this really what in her mind and the feelings lingering in her heart? What lies behind “the spirit of democracy” and how should we interpret it in the context of Tsunemori’s story? As her final refusal to the Sybil system stating that “it should not be the society to determine a future for the people. It should be the people to choose a future for the society.” She is not satisfied because under the control of the Sybil system, she sees no room for genuine autonomous choices. However, we still need to ask what does it truly mean to have choices for the people in the society? What does it mean to Tsunemori, if she admitted that her friend once lived a happy life without thinking much about choices and autonomy? 


In the newly released Psycho-pass movie, we are able to compare a Sybil system society with a more primitive form of social order—a community of a rebel army. After his exile, Kōgami left Japan and went to this region to help the rebel army to resist the implement of the Sybil system. Tsunemori encountered him and tried to convince him to go back to Japan. She failed, but she also once again experienced genuineness in the interactions with Kōgami and witnessed a sense of brotherhood and family-hood in the community of the rebel army which she could seldom feel in the Sybil system society. They are something that can even be nurtured in a chaotic and unstable society but cannot exist in a peaceful psycho-pass society. Certain essential elements for an individual to become a human being have been shadowed by the order of absolute justice of the Sybil system society. 


Consequently, as a lonely figure that stands in the whole system, Tsunemori's dissatisfaction also derives from a natural longing as an ultimate individual. It is a longing for companionship, for friendship, for a kind of intimacy that includes trust and deep mutual understanding, for those human interactions which can penetrate one’s heart and soul, for forming relationships which we can find in this show that only self-determined individuals are capable of. A life that is not ultimately self-determined cannot nurture such relationships, and sacrifice would be meaningless in this Sybil system society. Without struggles for autonomous choices when one is faced with a dilemma, and without a certain degree of sacrifice for another human being or for values larger than oneself, a deep personal relationship and genuine mutual understanding cannot be formed. Such a friendship will be missing when there is not enough room for deeply emotional tangling and a choice made fully upon one’s will. It is ironic that in the show the enemies of the system and whom despised by the system often have more trust and mutual understandings with each other. Instead, the attempts to self-define and the pursuits of autonomous choices in interpersonal relationship within the system lead to scenarios like son against father or friendship abandoned. Therefore, Tsunemori's rejection to the Sybil system can also be seen as a natural response and a renouncement. A response to a society that eliminated every single self-determined individual. And a renouncement to a system that should be responsible for her loneliness. 


Then it becomes evident that the truly excluded in this society is not people with unstable mental state, but individuals with a self-autonomous mind. The dystopian feature of this fictional world finally emerges in the full scale, and it is the extinguishment of the self-determination. The Sybil system society is not one filled with tyranny, disorder, or sense of insecurity. It is a peaceful and just society, yet after all, a “slavenised” one. People become slaves in respect that they have to give up the ultimate self-determination in order to live a peaceful and happy life. Although it is imaginable that they still possess an amount of choices in their daily life, the area for autonomy is limited and has been delineated. Within this sphere they can be free from interference, even make self-realisation to a certain degree, but still it can be said that they live a slave-like life because once exceeding this sphere, they are no longer masters of themselves and the final realisation of ones life is determined by the whole system. People degraded to the worst form of “the last man” in the sense of Kojeve’s and Fukuyama’s conceptions. A full self-realisation becomes impossible, since the final source of control, to determine someone to do this rather than that, lies beyond one’s sphere of autonomy. 


From this perspective, the spirit of democracy that the producer of this show talked about, and the statement Tsunemori made when she rejected the system, are all demonstrations of self-autonomy, other than the procedures of democracy per se. And the revolution that was tried by Makishima in the first season, was not equipped with a better social envision, instead, it was just an attempt to reclaim the right of self-determination from the whole system. 


And more importantly, the image of a slave is actually first and foremost represented not by an individual in the society, but by the Sybil system itself. Before it incorporated itself into the whole system, this socio-political order is at most an autocratic one. After the combination of the Sybil system and the society, a full circle of absolute control has been created, and no one or any group could evade this cage of “absolute justice”. From now on, even the Sybil system cannot turn the direction of the society, and becomes a slave of this whole system for it also loses the control to determine itself to do this rather than that. More like a highly efficient machine that execute an absolute will, the logic of actions has been set beforehand and the later will cannot exceed this. Moreover, collective measurement means that the sphere for personal autonomy is further decreased, and the worst scenario would be that it would rule out any room and possibility for genuine self-determination, since everything becomes collectively based and each personal action can be scrutinised by a collective. Finally, a solution that was meant to solve the problem of the Sybil system has made it into a complete form of dystopia, a dystopia that extinguish any possibilities for personal autonomy in the practice of a true absolutely just order. Wisely enough, in the last scene of the second season, the Sybil system pointed out this possible scenario to Tsunemori, and attributed it to her decision. Tsunemori, on the other hand, holds a more positive prospect of the evolution of the society. Although I doubt there will be any further authentic solutions and a way out, I look forward to the subsequent stories, if there would be any.

After watching the first season of psycho pass a few months back, I was extremely excited when I heard about season 2. Now it has just finished and I cant say I am disappointed but at the same time it wasn't perfect. It felt like they couldn't fit it all into 11 episodes and it was squeezed in there. When you see  the final episode you might understand, it felt like so much happened in 24 minutes, they could've fit all of that with more detail into a few episodes. Anyways, to the ratings.
Story 10/10: 
Despite it feeling rushed I thought the plot wasbrilliant, the ideas were amazing. I would like to list a few but I wont spoil, however it is definitely worth watching just for the story all together, that's how good it was.


Art 9/10: 

The area and scenery of the anime was decent, sometimes I didn't really know where they were or how they got there though. But for the art itself it looks like they did a pretty good job.


Sound 10/10:

I was a fan of the OST from the first season and cant say this OST bothers me, kinda nice. As for other sounds in the show they did a pretty good job it felt like the sounds went perfectly for stuff like the dominator.


Character 9/10: 

Everything was good except kamui's character looked a bit odd, I cant really pick out what it is just something doesn't look right haha. Overall its not really that bad though.


Enjoyment 9/10:

I did enjoy this but definitely not as much as the first season. I have to say though I was excited to watch a new episode every Thursday because I was wondering what would happen next, most anime's I would just wait a few days after the episode release and then watch. So this shows something I suppose :p


Overall 9/10: 

As I said before psycho pass season 1 was much better, if you haven't seen that for some reason and you are already hitting season 2, go watch that first and then come here. But overall it was a very good anime and I probably would rewatch it eventually.


Hope this review helped, pls watch this anime!!

TLDR: Still good, but missing some elements from PP1
Should you watch this if you've watched the first one? It may not be necessary, but I feel like the hole for wanting more that I had in my heart has been filled. 
The art and sound were very consistent with the first season. The animation quality is superb; the character's design is beautiful and the scenery (and imagery) presented is nice to look at. 9/10 for art. The OP and ED are some of the best for fall 2014. I listened to both for each episode and greatly enjoyed it. All the other music fits nicewith what is being illustrated. 9/10 for sound.


The characters continuing from last season held up, but were dragged back by the less engaging Togane and Mika. Kirito was a great villain (not as fun to watch as Makeshima), and made up for that a bit, but the new characters weren't up to par with the Ginoza and Kogami sidestories from the first season. 6/10


The story wasn't too riveting and felt off, somehow. It was ok overall, but what was missing was the sidelined characters in place of an uninteresting Mika + Togane route. It felt like it didn't lead to anything and didn't surpass my expectations. 5/10


I still greatly enjoyed this, my second favorite show for thursday's in fall 2014 (Shigatsu 2 stronk). Every episode was consistent from the start. Where other series' may start worse and snowball into something fantastic, PP2 starts at about 75% intensity and stays there; this, of course, means that it doesn't pick up hard near the end.  7/10


Overall, I'd give it an 72/100, or 7/10. Not great, still good, but missing those key characters from PP1. If you've watched the first season, this is a must watch.

I'm honestly so confused on why Psycho-Pass gets so much hate... I was looking at some reviews before I went into season 2 and saw allot of people saying "Just skip it, it'll make the anime much better" but that's not necessarily the case. I expected season 2 to be kind of like FMA Brotherhood's movies, complete trash and honestly not worth watching even if you loved FMA as much as I did. But Psycho-Pass 2 wasn't anything like that.
Don't get me wrong, i'm not saying that Psycho-Pass 2 holds up to season one. Season one was absolutely AMAZING, season 2 wasn't the same. Isuspect that season 2 was hated so much because unlike season 1, it didn't have you hooked and didn't make you think as much. It was like a lazy version of season one. Well I admit that was disappointing considering the reason I loved season one so much was because of how it made you think and generally felt allot smarter and well done, I wouldn't say it was bad because of that. Season 2 was nothing when compared to season one... However that's the problem, you're comparing it to season one. 


Comparing season 1 and season 2 is really a BAD decision, see season one was this beautiful masterpiece of mystery and literature. It was an anime that not everyone was going to get the references to literature quotes. Season 2 doesn't focus on that at all, season 2's goal was to take this corrupted government and finish off it's story. They didn't focus on making this huge story with layers and layers of information to unveil. Most of this was because of two reasons. 1. Season 2 only had 11 episodes and fitting in lots of detail would leave little time to close out the show in a proper manner. 2. Season 1 consumed most of the mysteries about the government so they only thing they could reveal secrets about is the new staff and Kamui.


Season 2 is nothing when compared too season 1, but comparing season one to season 2 is like comparing a professional athlete to someone on a high school team. Of course the professional athlete is going to be better than the person on a highschool team, he's had more time to practice so all around he's going to be a better player. But that doesn't mean that the highschool player is bad... I definitely think you should at least give season 2 a shot, it's not as bad as people make it out to be.

Psycho-Pass 2 is a disgraceful continuation of Psycho-Pass. The mediocre execution of Psycho-Pass is extenuated to a new low. Nothing in the first season was inherently bad, yet that is not the case here. The sound directing, voice acting, directing, pacing, etc. is all executed poorly. I would love to give it a (1), BUT, it at least tries to be good. It extends on its premise. Even if it does so completely nonsensically. It makes sense in the eyes of the anime and in the eyes of the creator. For that and that alone, this avoids a score of (1) from me. Given thatwe understand what it's trying to do, we shouldn't judge it so harshly. Regardless, don't watch this. It's complete trash and it doesn't make much sense, in any matter. It starts really bad, then it somewhat stabilizes and ends on a high note (again, assuming it made sense in the writer's eyes).

Psycho-Pass 2 has an ability to keep you wanting to watch the next episode. While I often see a lot of complaints about the story, I honestly didn't have an issue with it until the very end. Yeah, it mimics a lot of the same things from the first season so it might come out as stale, like the main villain having a psycho-pass that can't be read, but his true motives and the like remain hidden and there are more moving parts within these 11 episodes.
The pacing is wonderful right until the last episode when things go a little out of whack. Each plottwist and reveal is done at the perfect time. You just think you know whats going to happen next when they toss you a complete curveball, and not one from left field, but one that you kind of see in your peripheral but brush aside until it's right in front of you.


The characters though, are not very compelling. Akane, while as a character is awesome, is not challenged at all this season like she was in the first one and therefore nothing really happens to her. If anything she's a major hand in bringing the conclusion. Kamui has an interesting plan but he himself is somewhat boring. Don't get me wrong, he has a lot of backstory, but he takes a step back to his plan. Mika (the recruit from the end of S1) was a chance to do something with a blank slate, but instead they just use her as an annoyance. Oh, and Tougane, they telegraph hes bad news from the start, but when they reveal why and his "ability" it seems like a bad plot device.


The animation and action are very good. Maybe the animation is not as good as the first season, but as a visual show it's very pleasing to watch. Even the combat sequences are well thought out. It also has a noticeably fitting soundtrack.


Psycho-Pass S2 is a well crafted ride with bland characters. Not even overall bad characters, just ones that are not fleshed out or dont get treatment. They don't even serve a purpose to give another character development, because of a widespread mindset of refusal to change, ironically, it's the Sybil system itself that changes the most in the show, and the change is somewhat underwhelming to what could have happened.


PP2 has a lot of missed opportunities, but it does a lot in the 11 episodes it has to work with. 7/10

Psycho-Pass 2 is really good. I found it more enjoyable than season 1 because the first half of season 1 was more of an introduction. The second half turned into the chase and the actual plot. What I loved about the second season is that it is far more darker that the first. There is far more death, blood, and so forth which made it extremely enjoyable. The plot itself was really good, but I feel that something that was lacking in season 2 was the characters. I absolutely despised certain characters. I actually wished death upon them. Either way, season 2 is really enjoyablebecause of the amount of mystery in it. It made its cliff hangers really well, always having you want to come back. Overall, season 2 did a great job.

TL;DR – Bad story, boring characters, good art, OK sound, frustrating to watch.
The show has a pretty clear idea/premise that it feeds down your throat at every chance: “A future where our lives are controlled by computers is flawed; here is an 11 episode anime about why.” The creators must’ve thought that the idea was cool and interesting (and it is), but they also must’ve looked over the fact that any cool idea quickly becomes dreadfully boring when repeated a million times just in other words. Watching this show is like being in science class: We know that “f=ma” but the teacher just keeps givingus problems to practice how to use this really simple equation. 

The first season had the same problem of repeating itself and rehashing old ideas/concepts/ideas; it was a shame to see it repeated in the second season. Especially because after the main story of the first season was over, the only reason to watch this show was for its new characters and possibly different plot. But instead the second season is just more repetition of the “why computers ruling humans is bad” idea.


On top of the story being incredibly boring and repetitive, the characters are also uninteresting and stale. In the first 6 episodes we were introduced to 6 new characters (new in the sense that they were introduced in this season, not carried over from season 1) that we, the viewers were supposed to care about. By episode 6, one of those characters had gotten less than 5 minutes of screen time, two had died (one of which in the same episode they were introduced), one had changed personalities with a complete 180 without any explanation, and the other was extremely annoying (so much that I had to skim through her dialogue). The only new character that I showed the slightest bit of interest was Enforcer Sakuya Tougane, who seemed to be up-to-something which I unfortunately will never know because I have to drop this god-awful show right now. To sum this paragraph up: the viewer can’t give a single shit about any of these unmemorable, stale, and seemingly disposable characters, while interesting characters are the second biggest selling point of a season two following a successful season one.


The art is exceptional as it is very well made. The colorization is very dark and pale, which creates a certain aesthetic that compliments the story. The art style is actually very good at making gore look realistic, to the point that some scenes really had my stomach turn. The only negative comment I have is that the way peoples’ eyes are drawn is eerie to me. 


The sound design is terrible. Sound effects are repeated a lot with no variation, stock sounds are used (listen whenever something metal is hit), and there isn’t too much attention to detail. Sound effects are only used for big events you can’t miss. Meaning you won’t hear small details like a chair exhaling when someone sits down. I personally love it when a show goes above and beyond with sound design with small touches like that. The only reason why I raised the score from a 3 to a 4 is the soundtrack, which is really catchy.


Now the misc. section where I can rant:


What the fuck is up with this world? The story goes on in this futuristic dystopian statist Japan where the government keeps records on everything about its citizens including their mental health and the police can’t remotely shut down their own military servers? Who the fuck was in charge of cyber security? How couldn’t the fucking military detect thousands of random TCP connections to their servers? Aside from that, why don’t guns exist? I was told by someone that “people in that world are doctored to trust the dominators unconditionally, they don’t know any better” which I think is bullshit. If two seasons aren’t enough for the police to go “Huh. These dominators almost never work against the type of irregular cases that we investigate and have cost the department more than a dozen lives. Maybe we should stop using weapons that are software based and prone to failure and switch to manual firearms”, I don’t know what is? Three seasons? How long until these characters overcome autism and realize that pointing a software controlled gun at a criminal that obviously can bypass detection (which we know because they have clearly shown us that they can in the past 5 episodes) doesn’t work?

As you can tell, the story is full of pot-holes and illogical things that make it very hard to watch. The tipping point for me was episode 6 because of how retarded it was, and now I wonder how I every kept going after episode 4. 

And before you call me autistic or overly-attentive, watch the show yourself and tell me it doesn’t make you frustrated that they would rather remove the holo from the game in episode 6 and risk citizen psycho-passes to be clouded rather than just shutting the game down entirely (which should be super easy to do given that the government, hence the police, has direct fucking root access to the server).

Justice will be served...maybe.
Psycho Pass 2. For me personally, this has been long awaited. Sadly it does not impress me how the first season had. Firstly the basis here is weird. It starts off pretty damn good, the middle was iffy, and the end was anti-climatic. Being only eleven episodes, I wasn't expecting much; but what I got was...alright.
Kamui, Kirito is the main antagonist here, and while at first he may seem quite mysterious and interesting, it quickly devolves into a lazy revenge plot that really leads nowhere. Some of the characters this time around felt rather dull, too. Akane was way too uptight andShimotsuki, her "sidekick" was rather dull, and sometimes annoying.


With all the bad comes...some good though. While this season was definitely a huge letdown it definitely has its perks. For one, the music and sound is all great - - love the OP/EDs. The art however, does feel like a slight step down from the first season. Not too much detail this time around.


So all in all I was disappointed. I can only really recommend this to anyone who's either a die-hard fan of the first season, or really likes cyberpunk. It's a 7.4/10 from me.

Note: This review assumes you've read my one for the first season and have seen that season, as it will contain a couple of spoilers for that season.
Overview:
When "Psycho Pass" first aired in 2012, it took the anime world by storm with its Blade Runner-esque setting and highly compelling action and characters. Two years later, "Psycho Pass 2" attempted to continue the trend, but unfortunately fan opinions are split, to say the very least. Having seen the second season myself, however, I have to say I enjoyed it quite a lot, and believe that anyone who's seen the first season should at least check outthis one, even if it isn't quite as good as the first.


Story & World (8.5/10):

If there's one area "Psycho Pass 2" does improve upon compared to the first season, it's the story. Set a year and a half after the original, the now veteran Inspector Akane Tsunemori discovers that a whole new threat to the Sibyl system has emerged, in the form of a mysterious man named Kirito Kamui who, much like Makishima, is undetectable by Sibyl and has been committing mysterious crimes in secret. It is apparent largely from the start that the Kamui is not simply murdering at random but is in fact performing a massive experiment with one central purpose: finding out how exactly the Sybil system works, by studying the system's signature weapon, the Dominator. Once again, it's up to Akane, along with the Enforcers and her new partner Mika Shimotsuki, to track down this mysterious figure and bring him to justice.


What makes the story better than that of the first season is that it's not obvious exactly what direction things are going in, and there are some genuine surprises here and there. We're also finally given some genuine insight into the Sibyl system and exactly how it came to be, learning not only about the system’s origin but also about the possible alternatives to it and how they were ultimately dealt with. This in turn fleshes out the setting in new and interesting ways and sets the stage for upcoming iterations of the franchise, such as the trilogy of movies which are due to be released next year.


Speaking of the Sibyl system, that brings me to another compelling part of the story- the morality. While the Sibyl system has always been portrayed as seriously flawed, here this is taken to a whole new level, as it has descended into complete hypocrisy, allowing a true psychopath to roam free while executing dozens of honest people who have done nothing but discover its secret. Kamui is also portrayed as being a lot more sympathetic than Makishima, as he genuinely wants to help people rather than just cause chaos. It gets to the point that if it weren't for Akane, who is still as heroic as they come, Kamui would come off as the GOOD guy. This does a fine job at ramming in messages that were only scraped upon in the first season, namely that it's wrong to judge people by who they are rather than what they have done, and as nice as it would be to get rid of someone before they are able to commit a crime, such a thing is not only impossible, it's just plain unfair. Admittedly, some may find the whole thing a bit rushed, as it's only half the length of the previous season, but overall, I consider the story to be a major improvement.


Art & Animation (8.5/10):

If you've seen the first season, the visuals will be very familiar, and that's a very good thing. They have aged brilliantly over the years and the characters and environments still look fantastic. Unfortunately, there is one really big problem within all of this- the gore. The use of gruesome imagery like people exploding when shot with the Dominator was a common criticism of the previous season, and what do the writers do? They turn it up to even higher levels! There's even a scene where people are running out of a building and are all shot by Dominators, so we get to see one gratuitous explosion after another. There is also more than a bit of body mutilation and physical torture, both implied and plain for all to see. I actually came very close to throwing up a couple of times, as the series is just that excessively violent.


Sound & Dialogue (9.5/10):

Once again, the sound of "Psycho Pass" absolutely steals the show. There aren't many noteworthy tracks that weren't in the previous season, but considering how good the music was, there didn't really need to be. The voice acting is also just as good as it was in the first season, as not only do all the returning characters keep their voices, but there are also a number of new voice actors including Colleen Clinkenbeard, Christopher Sabat and Monica Rial (three of my all-time favourites). The only thing that keeps the sound from getting 10 is that it lacks all the literature references there were in the previous season, though I found this to be forgivable.


Characters (8/10):

This is unfortunately one area that's definitely not as good as the first season. The biggest reason for this is the absence of Shinya Kogami, who, due to the end of the first season, is restricted only to a couple of cameo appearances here, which some may find disappointing. Taking his place is Mika Shimotsuki, whom some may remember as the school girl from the previous season, who lost two of her friends to a psychopath. Because of her past, Mika has a very biased opinion of latent criminals, believing that if the Sibyl system says they deserve to die, they do, no questions asked. While this does allow us to see things from a perspective other than Akane's, it also makes her, for a lack of a better word, a bitch. However, we see that she has a good relationship with Yayoi, who comforted her after losing her friends, so it's clear that she at least has the decency to accept that there's one decent person among latent criminals.


Another point of issue is the new villain, the aforementioned Kirito Kamui. I said before that he would come off as the hero if it weren't for Akane, but whether or not you'd root for him is a different matter. While he's certainly terrifying for the first few episodes, due to him performing experiment after experiment to find out the functions of the Dominator, as we learn more about him, he starts to feel like less of a character and more of an odd entity (I won't spoil how, of course), and ultimately feels rather underwhelming compared to Makishima, even if he is certainly more sympathetic. Ultimately, it's not the character himself that compelled me, but his goals, actions and motivations. 


Now we'll move on to the good parts. Akane was already my favourite character, but here she absolutely steals the show. In the first episode alone, she shows just how far she's come since her recruitment by calmly using her negotiation skills to talk down a criminal who was using bombs to attack the PSB, which gets his Psycho-Pass into the non-danger zone, allowing her to stun him and bring him in instead of killing him. It really is amazing to see how she's able to retain her optimism and idealism even after everything she's seen and been through. Additionally, there's a number of great new characters to replace the old ones, Ginoza is no longer the asshole he was in the previous season, and while it is very hard to like Mika at times, her character is ultimately well-rounded and sympathetic.


Enjoyment (8/10):

I have to be honest; while it is great that the writers have improved on the story considerably over the first season, it's come at the cost of it being a pretty depressing watch. It really shows that the Sibyl system isn't a law worth protecting, no matter how necessary it may be to maintain the peace. Then, there's all the psychological torture that various characters are put through- including Akane as the villains push against her natural ability to rebound from psychological stress and attempt to break her irrevocably. In other words, there are more than a few truly messed up moments and if you don't have the stomach for it, well, that's perfectly understandable.


Overall:

"Psycho Pass 2" is a worthy sequel to the fantastic original season. It won't win prizes for pacing and some of the new characters are a bit iffy, but as second seasons go, this is one I believe any fan of the first season should at least try, even if not everyone will be satisfied. For more on "Psycho Pass", be sure to await my review for the 2015 movie, which I hope to have written by the end of the year.


Score:

8.5+8.5+9.5+8+8=42.5/50=8.5/10

Let's see apart from the timeskip takes place which is Akane ; the one and only main character other than her past comrades and more new characters was introduced. Besides that, this isn't really feel a sequel to me
Of course it's the different one..
The plot was indeed not the same as season 1 which is utilized when the Sibyl System has been planning to put a collective entity in the system so that Sibyl must judge itself, so nothing too complex there. A collective Psycho-Pass would mean that groups of people could be judged as dangerous even though each individual was clear, or that people'sPsycho-Pass could change when within different groups, or like the twist at the end with Kamui - who claims that the person holding the Dominator becomes collectively part of Sibyl when pointing it at Sibyl itself.\n\n
Based of the fact of how the sequel will turn.. Nah It doesn't the same without Gen Urobuchi directly manage the story...but hey! they manage to adapted the whole story in the end by not failing it\n\n
Overall 9/10 Worth Watch : If you're just gonna skip the second one and already watch the movie... You're gonna get confused on what the movie is all about.. The story is important too even it's just a filler or some parts which is connected. You know?

First things first. I love the first season of Psycho-Pass. It left me wanting more. And when I heard that a Season 2 is coming out, I got all hyped up. Now as I write this, I just finished watching the final episode earlier and I should say... it has it's ups and downs. Why? Carry on reading...
So basically, it once again focused on Akane on being an Inspector. I was actually shocked at the end of Season 1 wherein Ginoza was demoted to being an Enforcer. But hey, he looked better without glasses! There is still Yayoi and Shion (which is pratiacally is hookingup with each other XD) which is a good sight to see. Technically it's just them that remained from the original cast of Season 1. Kougami was nowhere to be found. Yeah he appeared but only on Akane's mind, so it kind of disappoints me.


And we are introduced with a new set of Enforcers, Sakuya Togane and Shou Hinakawa. (Oh I adore Hinakawa so much!) Then there's the Junior Inspector Mika Shimotsuki. I'll get to them later.


Kicking off where Season 1 ended, Akane is faced once again with a new villain (?) named Kirito Kamui. Unlike Makishima Shougo, Kamui has a different goal. He wants to judge Sibyl. And by that, he played with the people of MWSPB (i dunno if I put it correctly). But as the series progresses, you wouldn't even know who the real villain is. From there, plot twists ensues.


I can safely say that if you haven't enjoyed the first season, there's no point in watching this one. For me, I do enjoyed it although it has some flaws.


Firstly, Mika's characterization. I do feel that the series pretty much "butchered" her character. Yes, she may appear "bitchy" for the most part of the series, but when you look deeper, she is just following orders from Sibyl. She technically don't know what she is doing. Therefore, she is just another victim of Sibyl's flaws. The reason why I said her character was butchered is because of the lack of her characterization. The show primarily just showed her really annoying attitude towards everybody. Yet, it wasn't revealed as to why she acts like that. It appears that she is just a natural bitch. But I strongly believe that there is more to that. The show can use some background stories for her but they didn't, so I don't exactly know what to feel about Mika's character.


Next up, the lack of episodes. 11 episodes is not enough for this one. When I first knew that it will be just 11 episodes, I was like: "Oh, that would appear rushed."... and I was right. If only this series was also 22 episodes like the first season, they can use the chance to give some more characterization to Mika and a deeper explanations to everything that is happening to the series.


Now to mention everything I liked about it:


Firstly, Akane's maturity. OMG she just got so badass!! I love her for that!


Next, OP and ED songs. Got me LSS'ed for a looooong time! XD


The plot twist. Every information leaked is really interesting. The turn of events made my jaw drop. Like really. But that is not quite effective because the OP sequence pretty much revealed everything that is happening to this season.


The brutality. OMFG. In my opinion, this is more brutal than the first season. Like really! MORE BLOOD!


Animation: Yup, pretty awesome~


Overall.... I'd give it a 8.5 out of 10. I was actually entertained. But yeah, the flaws just don't made me feel so hyped up. By the end of this season, I was actually hyped for the Movie coming out on January. Hopefully we get more Kougami. HAHAHA!

The original Psycho Pass was a great anime that combined great characters, action art and everything else that makes a good anime. You wont find much of that here. 
     The thing that was most troubling about this anime was the characters. While I wasn't disappointed by the lack of Kogami in this series, I was very disappointed in the other characters. Previously, all the characters had great depth and you really got to know them. That sort of character interaction is not here. While of course it would be harder to explain all the charactersin an 11 episode season rather than a 24 episode one, the lack of character depth here is pathetic. Many of the characters get little to downright no explanation in this series. That was one of the strong points in the original series. It is sad not to see it here. \n
     The story wasn't half bad, but nothing special. it also felt unexplained at times, however it felt captivating at times, just nowhere near the quality of the first season. \n
     The art, like the first season is spectacular, no complaints here. It also sounded great. I have yet to find a Psycho Pass intro I didn't like.\n
     Overall this anime was fine, but a bit of a let down. I thought the first season ended perfectly, and that the anime wasn't in need of a second season. Maybe a movie would suffice to finish things up. We will be getting one in January.  It didn't seem like a cash grab, but more of an un-necessary addition. If you're into the series though, I think it may be worth the watch. Give it a try if you're bored one day. It wont live up to the first season, but it's fine nonetheless.

As I watch the first season of psycho pass come to an end, it lingered to mind of what will come off on the second season of this show. To be honest, I didn’t set my expectations high, as it may failed to equal or exceed the actions, excitement and enjoyment I’ve seen. It’s slightly true though.
One thing I like about psycho pass is the thrill and the hype that will make you finish it in one sitting. In season 2, though the ‘thrill and the hype’ lowered, but its plot is definitely more interesting than it was in season 1.  Here are thereasons why I think so:


1.	It has more intriguing antagonist. He was like Makishima who uses other people to set up his plan. But the way he made is plan is way much cooler and cleverer, which makes the ‘game’ exciting.


2.	 Characters showed some changes. (I only point out two because of all characters, because the changes in them are more evident.)


•	Akane – changed physically and mentally.  What I’m referring to is her eyes. It makes her look sharper and smarter.  This maybe a small thing but it changed how I view her.  The way she thinks is more like Kougami now.  


•	Ginoza – being demoted to an Enforcer, he showed more human-like feelings now. Lol


3.	Professor Saiga Jouji has more screening time. His strengths are thoroughly used in their investigation.

4.	Unfolding of truth behind the mystery of their enemy each and every episodes will make you finish it in one go. 

5.	How Akane played with the hands of sibyl is still very entertaining. 

6.	Surprises are there, which are crazy lol.


One thing only lacks psycho pass 2 is Kougami. And I realized as I watch is that he is the “thrill and the hype” element of psycho pass. Without him, for me, psycho pass isn’t complete. After all, he was also a main character besides Akane. Aaannnd to be honest I am intrigued by Akane’s actions. It seems to me that she misses Kougami. The fact that she lights Kogami’s cigarette brand to smell it.  Something’s fishy there.  


For some reason many didn’t like season 2, but for me, it’s still okay. Music, animation, character designs are pretty much the same as season 1. 


PS: forgive me if there were any errors on what I have written. To err is human 

Holy crap! The first season got a score of 8.55 and the second season got a 7.69? That's horrible. People must really didn't like this second season since there was so much of a difference in the scores.
Anyway, if there is one thing I can agree on, is that the first season was definitely better than this one but not by a drastic margin. If they force paced this season into 20+ episodes I would understand, but at 11 episodes, I found the story told quite well. One of the other reasons why I feel the first season was better than this was because ofthe OST. The anime background music was much more intense in the first season than it was in this second one. An anime's score has a lot to do with how much you get into it. How much you'd feel a thrill, and it affects how you perceive the action as well.


I still really enjoyed this sequel, and at times I asked myself, "who the hell comes up with these ideas?" and that's a good thing because I enjoy stuff that puts me to contemplate. The use of paradoxes in this season was awesome!


I gave the first season of Psycho-Pass a 10/10... for this season season, having said what I felt was different and could have been better, I give a 9/10!

I don't get why the second season is gets so much hate. Maybe a lot of this goes over people's heads. True, it doesn't have much character development, but the story and the villain's goal is so interesting. They don't flesh out the villain but it's not about him, it's about his goal. The whole concept of the second season makes it worth watching. It's thrilling and makes you think.
Although, i do concede to people's point that the "make people's color black and make mother look prettier" isn't really explained and the explanation that he's crazy might be pretty flimsy. Even her junior is plainannoying most of the time. By fleshing some of these character's out more, the show could've been much better overall but it's still definitely a great thriller to watch. Not too far from season 1 for a season with 11 episodes.

I want to begin my review saying that I loved so much the first season of Psycho-Pass that I was scared of watching the second one; so, if you're feeling the same, I'm here to tell you you shouldn't!
Introduction. //
First of all, I have to say that there's a huge difference between the first and the second season: 
1. If you're expecting to find all the same characters and the same things of the first season, then you'll be disappointed (and I guess you should re-watch the first one?); because this is a sequel and we find all the consequences of the actions that weremade in the first season. \n
2. In my opinion, in the first season there were more overwhelming feelings and emotions, while the second season focuses more on rational thoughts and the development of personality and feelings. \n\n
Plot. //\n
The story centers around Akane and her division facing a new abnormal case. They have to capture Kamui that is acting against the Sybil System. Every episode give new (confusing) clues about his motive.\n
It is a really simple, linear story but it gets always more intense, episode after episode, and every new discover, every questions take almost a philosophical meaning and that's what made me fall in love even more in Psycho-Pass. \n\n
Conclusion. //\n
Pros: \n
- simple, but meaningful story\n
- amazing music with Ling Tosite Sigure and Egoist\n
- twists and mystery\n\n
Cons: \n
- they could make it a little longer, even though it's fine like this\n
- some scenes are predictable for someone who's into thriller stuff, still good for me

If you watched psycho pass season 1 and you're looking for an extension of the story, this is worth your time. Season 2 brings some really good action and mini-plot setups that will bring quite a bit of enjoyment. The moments of tensions are great, and the philosophical debates are still there. However, season 2 as a whole is essentially an inferior copy of season 1, and with half the length it wasn't able to delve nearly as deep as the original. At the end you will probably ask yourself whether the 11 episodes made sense, which is not what a show should do.
**spoilers
The maingripe I had with season 2 was the ending, which seems to be the problem that most other people have. The primary fault lies with the portion where the sybil system itself is judged, contradicting certain truths that were established during season 1 and the fact that the sybil system's judgment is so easily swayed after hearing just a handful of words... it didn't feel right. \n\n
I also have the say that the disappearance of Kogami, and the fact that our MC spends lots of time hallucinating about him doesn't match up with the fact that we see no attempt by her to find him. This might be answered in another arc taking place between the ending of 1 and the 1.5 years that follow.

Comparing season 1 to this will show us a really really huge gap in terms of the quality both shows can offer. As a huge fan of the Psycho-Pass series, I try my best to not take into consideration of comparing this season with the first too much, and instead just try to enjoy the show as it is without being too biased. Without further ado, I would like to continue on in this review on my take of Psycho-Pass 2.
Story:
Psycho-Pass 2 takes place 1 and a half years after the first season ended, and I believe that the production crew of season 1 wantedto focus on the movie and allowed another team to handle season 2 while still overseeing their work. Psycho-Pass 2 is meant to be a bridge to link the movie and the first season, by introducing new characters that will appear in the movie and letting the viewers see more of what the Sybil System is truly like. The antagonist in this show goes by the name of Kamui Kirito and he has a rather unique story to his life. Just like Makishima Shougo from season 1, Kirito's objectives of committing crimes are to be able to get to the Sybil System. The first few episodes will be rather painful to watch because characters are dumb in them and the plot is very messy, I agree with people on these even though I love this series a lot. However, as the story goes deeper in, lots of secrets will be uncovered and revealed and they can be intriguing depending on how you portray them.


Art:

The art in Psycho-Pass 2 can be very inconsistent, the visual composition as compared to the first season is shown to have dropped a lot in quality. Character designs can sometimes look weird and horrendous, sometimes Akane just doesn't look like Akane at all, and therefore the reason for why I say that the art can be inconsistent. But that doesn't stop us from being able to be given a treat of some rather nice action scenes from time to time. I read somewhere that another studio took over the art and animation for this season and I believe that was the reason for all the rather disappointing art, hopefully the blu-ray quality will have improved overall art for the show. You will be able to see how different the art in season 2 is by either watching the Psycho-Pass movie trailer or just simply watch back a small scene from season 1, the quality difference is really huge.


Sound:

I do not really have any complaints for this section, I have always loved the soundtracks and voice acting in Psycho-Pass and this season didn't disappoint me in terms of that. Mika's voice actress does a really good job at portraying Mika's annoying attitude and Akane's voice actress is always doing her job well too.


Character:

We have been given quite a number of new characters in this season, but since this season is only 11 episodes, do not expect much character developments to occur here. I looked forward to seeing the partnership between Akane and Ginoza but nothing much happens which led me to a little disappointment, and some characters only gets a few brief lines of explanations about them and I just felt like that was the reason for the lack of character development (as compared to Yayoi getting one whole episode that tells the story of how she became a latent criminal in season 1). So yes, I highly doubt there is any powerful character development in this season as compared to how brilliantly Kougami and Makishima were developed in season 1. I do like how much Akane have grown here, she started off as a little naive girl and now she is one of the most badass characters in this show.


Enjoyment:

I still enjoyed myself a lot when watching Psycho-Pass 2, the thrill that I get whenever I watch each episode as they release does make it a rather enjoyable experience for me as I've completed the show. In order to enjoy this season even though it can be quite the letdown, I suggest you to put your critics knowledge aside and just watch this show without wanting to point out every flaw in it. I do have times whereby I spotted a bunch of inconsistencies in the show but I told myself to cast them aside and when I do, I am just enjoying this show and showing my appreciation for it by really choosing to like it.


That is my review for Psycho-Pass 2, thank you for reading!

I had just finished Season 1, shortly before, and, yes, I was anxious to find out about Shinya! I read a fantastic review and character analysis on the characters before watching also. I wanted to keep an open mind. Yes, I was seriously disappointed Shinya wasn't in Season 2! 
But when you think about it, Season 2 has its high points. It's completely necessary to watch this season; yes, even before watching the movie. 
I loved season 2. To me, I feel like I could rewatch this season before watching Season 1. Why? I love how Akane's character grew. She was just a flower inseason 1; with Shinya's absence, she budded into a beautiful rose. Just watching her, in itself, gave me fulfilled enjoyment. \n
The action is still there, and so it the whole idea of Sybil. You're left to ponder to yourself, even if you don't agree with the lady protagonist, why she's still working for Sybil. Her answer is definitely insightful. \n
Now characters -- It broke my heart that practically a few branch of characters were introduced. It even was a little too much for my heart! \n
The purpose of Season 2, was to give you a fill-in for the movie, so you're not left behind. IT also, helps you see Akane's transformation. \n
Shinya isn't completely left out - his presence hasn't been forgotten, that is. Akane lights a cigarette, to remind herself of him and help her think like he would. \n
I have to say, I loved the criminals of Season 2. The finale isn't something you'd want to miss either. Kyaa!\n\n
Thing is, don't let yourself go in with the hype. Make your own judgement.

Story: 6
Psycho-Pass in general has a difficult time following the "show don't tell" method because it covers so much material each episode. This can lead to some alarming plot holes if not executed properly. Unlike the first season, Psycho-Pass 2 doesn't link together plot points very well. Even by the last episode, all of the evidence pieces feel like they were just taped together rather than being a part of a large puzzle. Some short cuts don't follow logic and were simply taken to get a point across. Overall, however, I still think the new plot, while somewhat unnecessary, was quite interesting. There were alot of clever and exciting ideas, but they just didn't always lead to something that entirely made sense. Perhaps 11 episodes just wasn't enough.


Art: 9

The art definitely lives up to expectations. Some of the gripes from the first season, such as weird angles of Tsunemori's face, have been fixed completely in this iteration. Like the ups of season 1, the animation is fluid and the cityscape is absolutely stunning. This is the expected quality for a 2014 animation.


Sound: 7

Overall, the show's music is nothing to complain about. While none of the background music stood out to me, all of the pieces worked well in depicting the show's atmosphere. The opening and ending both start out great and get me hyped, but always seem to fall off in the middle. I liked the first season's opening and ending much better. This may just be me, however, and I'm sure many viewers will love the new tracks. As for voices, most characters seem to have fitting and well done voices. Although, I did notice that Tsunemori's voice changed pitch a couple times.


Characters: 5

Returning characters come in with a solid foundation but receive little development throughout season 2. The new characters started off with interesting personalities, but seem under worked.


Akane Tsunemori: The main character of the series. While I think she is generally a likable character, I was disappointed by how little she was affected by her surroundings. By the second season she has become a veteran inspector. Her psycho-pass is extremely hard to cloud, but aside from being optimistic and moralistic in nature, there is no given explanation as to why she is "asymptotic." She suffers from many personal traumas in Psycho-Pass 2, but her character never changes much. She most likely could have held the same opinions in the finale right from episode 1. 


Mika Shimotsuki: The new inspector of Division 1. She comes off a bit as the stereotypical naive and ignorant girl who refuses to admit her own msitakes. While she has been on the job for two years, she somewhat resents Tsunemori's senior authority because unlike Tsunemori, Shimotsuki believes the enforcers should be used as nothing more than tools in solving crimes. She strictly plays by the rules which unsurprisingly leads to some problems. Her only real point of variation is her attraction and admiration for enforcer Yayoi Kunizuka for comforting her after the Oso Academy case. 


Nobuchika Ginoza: Ginoza from season 1 was awesome because he was such a conflicted character. Early on he gave advice to Tsunemori, and later found out that he was a complete hypocrite, falling victim to his stress/rage and being demoted to an enforcer. It's really disappointing that he is a complete supporting character in Psycho-Pass 2. He has one lackluster emotional scene, and after that pretty much serves as Tsunemori's advisor for the rest of the season.


Sakuya Togane: A new enforcer introduced in episode 1. Sadly, he comes off as a shady character immediately because of his portrayal in the opening. Seriously, don't give away the plot in the opening. It's not cool. But yeah, he appears to be very level-headed and agreeable, much like a replacement Kogami at the beginning. What frustrates me is that his change into his real self is so jagged, and the other characters show practically no interest in that. Not even Tsunemori. 


Sho Hakinawa: A new enforcer, and another stereotype. He's that typical depressed guy with a specific skill set and chooses to crouch in his chair. 


Kamui: The main antagonist of season 2. His major skill is making people do what he wants, but in a different manner that Makishima's. Also, unlike Makishima, he isn't out to destroy Sibyl, but is curious about Sibyl itself. 

 My complaint is that we never really understand how he achieves his amazing skills. Also, we later find out that his personal motivation doesn't really add up with his goals.


Enjoyment: 8

Although there are many issues that are hard to overlook with Psycho-Pass 2, it's hard to deny that it was a pretty fun ride. Every time I watch the show I get the immediate sensation of wanting to drop everything and become a detective. The violence is intense, but luckily isn't anything that will keep me up at night. Ultimately, while flubbing some plot components, Psycho-Pass 2 does teach us more about the Division 1 crew and the Sibyl System, and makes me eager for more Psycho-Pass in the future.

The first season of Psycho-Pass really did leave a huge impact on me but somehow while the second season is still good in my opinion, I can't help but feels this second season is just like a filler just to affirm Akane's character development in the first season. And because of that, I think this second season could not stand on its own without the first season in front of them making this second season is too dependent. While it's a bit disappointing, the second season is actually still fun and interesting to follow.
As stated in my first season review, I praised Psycho-Pass because ofits character development while still maintaining the major character trait untouched. While I was wishing for Akane's further character development, what did I get is only an affirmation of Akane's character development in the first season. This is stated by how the whole case seems like a test for Akane's character even Akane herself stated that in a monologue early in first few episodes. There's not much difference of how Akane viewed the Sybil from the beginning to the end of the season and for me that's a bit disappointing as Akane's view of Sybil was a leftover from the first season. Still, I love how the writer kept Akane in character and maintaining her major character traits those are kindness and her sense of justice even she is a bit rough after what happened in the first season and that is the part I love about this second season.


While not much explored, I love how they throw the hints of Akane who is still attached with Kogami. For me this is very important for Akane's character as Kogami was the one who built Akane's character in the first season. They can't just throw that away and because they keep him in Akane's mind, I think it is good enough.


The story line of this second season is pretty good in my opinion with a major theme of judgement. While being interesting enough, I can't help but feels the story line it's a little bit like a copy of the first season with the main villain's feeling is almost close with what Makishima's feeling in the first season and questioning the Sybil's judgement. It is still interesting but deeply in my heart, I really do want a new innovation in the story department to make myself stop comparing the second season with the first season.


The animations and soundtracks are still very impressive in my opinion maintaining its reputation from the first season. The opening performed by Ling Toiste Sigure and the ending performed by EGOIST of this season are so much rocking and made the hype level up to the roof proofing that both of them are really fit for rocking the Psycho-Pass universe.


Overall, while it is still interesting, the second season is too much dependent to what happened in the first season and overshadowed by them at the same. It made me could not stop comparing the first and the second season. I don't know if that's good or not but I think it is better to have a dependent second season so they could catch anyone who start the series a bit late.

the story is pretty good to me, just little bit feel the same like the first season but it's realy interesting , it's like telling u that the perfect sibyl system has more  weakness than police know. 
Maybe there is another season they still make, and in the end the sibyl system will be shuting down and people realized that there is no system is better than humanity and the human race will find their own way just like tsunemori said in 1st season. I really waiting for it.
what i regret is there's no more Kougami Shinya in main character, the fact that KougamiShinya is the real badass affect all the story. if tsunemori is the heart of psycho pass than Kougami is the soul of psycho pass. The heart without soul is just an empty body there's no passion no emotion in it,  You can't make the badass vanish like that ! \n
 When i think, it make sense why the Kougami is vanish from the 1st season, but I expect that he will back in 2nd season and kick the fucking sibyl system ass. I hope in the 3rd season psycho pass the badass will come back.\n
Actually I miss Kougami so bad :))

I heard the tales. While I was watching the original Psycho-pass, I looked into its second season to see what the general opinion was of it, and I heard... opinions. But I wanted to see how it was for myself, so after finishing season 1, I moved with trepidation over to season 2.
I'll get this out there, this season isn't terrible. It's more or less awful for how it is structured and what it represents. This season is more or less season 1 except cut down to a much shorter length. The characters mirror characters from the last season and generally fill their roles notas well. The largest issue with a shortened season is the fact that there is less time for everything to develop, so it just feels rushed and uninteresting.


The characters are boring and I don't like them. especially the villain and the character who takes up the position Akane had in the previous season. Sibyl is constantly stupid in this season and nothing of value is gained from watching this. This season also feels like it's spilling a bit too much unnecessary blood. In season 1, everyone who is shown dying feels realistic and necessary. In this season, it feels like people are dying simply for the shock factor, and not for the purpose of the story at large.


From what I've heard about the movie, it largely ignores season 2, so there is likely no reason you'd have to watch this show. Stick with the first season, and don't waste your time on this repetitive goo.

How do you live up to the first season of Psycho-Pass? A villain like Makishima, and two great lead characters in Tsunemori and Kogami, it's hard to top. And But I don't think that Psycho-Pass 2 is trying to top season 1, or even reinvent itself. Instead, it's a continuation, like if season 1 had been 11 episodes longer. And it succeeds incredibly in this sense, not feeling like a new show. I'll start off with the characters. The new cast of characters, and the old, are rather hit or miss, which was an issue with the first season. You have Tsunemori, a fantastic characterand the show protagonist again, and an enigmatic villain this season, yet no new character peaked my interest other than the villain, and that's because you know nothing about him until the final half of the show. The writers did a great job not giving this seasons villain the exact same motive as Makishima, and instead spicing it up, as well as adding a side villain. The new inspector seems to function as a foil to Tsunemori, acting irrationally at times, and seeming to think she is in competition with Tsunemori. She however does experience some satisfying character development by the end of the show. The other new characters like the red-haired enforcer just don't have enough development, and Ginoza and Yayoi are pretty much ignored in any development as well. Luckily, the story is what is gripping about this season. Like the first, this story is a deconstruction of itself. Urobuchi created the world of Psycho-Pass just to break all the rules, like "What happens if you can't read a criminals Psycho-Pass?". This season, while including some of the old deconstruction elements, is building up to something new and rule-breaking, and it is enthralling. Every week since it aired, I waited to find out what it will be. The new "twist" kind of let me down, though that stems from trying to compare Season 1's twist to this one's, and it felt rushed. The ending was also a pretty major let down, and doesn't really explain anything. The animation is good, nothing standout, apart from the brutality of the show. It's really taken a violent turn, and the animation luckily fits it well. The final half of the finale takes a noticeable dip in animation quality. The soundtrack is fantastic as well, with the OP and ED being some of the best this season. The actual OST is also very fitting, with a sci-fi feel to it to match the cyber-punk nature of the show. All-in-all, the best way I could think of this show was as a supplement to the movie, and to explain a bit of what has gone on between Makishima and the movie. The season as a whole felt rushed, mainly because they only focused on one case the whole time. The story was still alright however, and the soundtrack continued to be great, while the characters took a back seat to the story. Overall, 5/10.

My first ever review, but anytime this series comes to my sight, i feel like i have to share my opinion bout it. The 1st season was my first "omfg" anime series ever, with Makishima Shogo being my first and till, last "manlove" anime character. (Kogami was the "aaah he is so coool kawaii" guy that was put in for the  girls to dream about.) With his death, and without his presence the story lost its half, or even more than its half; and they give us one more season, i was happy at first too, trying to clone Makishima in the person of,Kamui?, and trying to force on us the same "magic" that Makishima had without him doing anything, but the other characters praising/ glorifying him to the point that it just became awkward. This is the main idea(the problem if the series) i would like to share with my review, i don't know if its understandable; Makishima himself built up his charisma slowly, step by step with every episode, they even had a talk with prof Saiga about the phenomena. He was a well built character supported with philosophy, art and literature just enough and not to much; personally he made me read more books than any of my school teachers(sadly). On the other hand Kamui did nothing the whole story, and the studio (tried) forced surrounding characters to build him up, with the only interesting, philosophical idea of the "omnipotent", which could have been settled in one episode. So in my opinion, as i look at the series, the second season is one empty bundle, to satisfy our superficial needs.
