PSYCHO PASS 2 COMPACT REVIEW
*This is my first review, I'll try my best to be spoiler free*
What's good:
+ The art is still is great as the first season (dark & gritty cyberpunk).
+ The sound dept is also as good as the first season.
+ One character (Hinakawa, the red haired guy) has the potential to be a good and relatable character if developed further in the next season
What's bad:
- The new writer (yes, this season's script is not written by Urobuchi) does not seem to grasp Urobuchi's concept of Psycho Pass and Sybil System, which cause inconsistencies between the first and this season.
- Most characters arelacking in development, and some characters from the first season felt out-of-character.\n\n
- Shimotsuki Mika, a character which purpose is just to annoy the watchers.\n\n
- Failing in building watchers emotion, because almost everything felt so rushed compared to the first season.\n\n
- Some gory and disturbing scenes lack momentum, which makes them felt like being added just because the first season has them.\n\n
- Felt more just like filler instead of a sequel.\n\n\n
Score:\n\n
Story: 5\n
Art: 9\n
Sound: 9\n
Character: 6\n
Enjoyment: 6\n
Overall: 7

A good sequel.
The story is very similar to the original and revolves around tracking down those who can not be judged by Sibyl. Here the situation has been changed with more focus put into a discussion on society. If you didn't like the all the psychological babble before, I have good news. There's even more. 
The art style has its ups and downs. The background color schemes are mostly gray or boring colors and feel slightly depressing to look at. Admittedly, its traditional to have a crime drama set in dark alleyways and poor lighted places so it maybe an aesthetic choice. Meanwhile the holodisplays and special effects are really good. Blood splatters and facial expressions are handled well too.


I don't have any problems with the sounds. The dominators sound good. The various technology chimes and blips manage to avoid being annoying. The voice acting was good from the subbed perspective. 


The characters are what make this show great. The MC was fully developed in the original show. Now she's set loose on the world. There's no need to analyze her behavior. Just sit back and watch one of the strongest female leads ever take charge. The other returning cast members are treated the same way and have almost no development time. Instead we are introduced to a couple of new characters that receive developmental attention. 


Enjoyment is going to be hit or miss. If you liked the first one, then this will be fine. I don't think of it as a step down, but it doesn't recapture the initial wonder of the original. New elements aren't added into the world and much of the story formula remains the same. 


Overall it's a solid sequel. It adds a few layers onto the story without changing direction. Not so much launching to new heights as a step in the right direction.

Akane, that unpredictable inspector back at it again, and more badass than ever, things are different now, new faces arrived, but the monster within still sleeping as deeply as it has throughout the whole first season, but it's time for it to go leach into the world and break havoc, would she withstand this new challenge? well, you tell me...
- Story(7.5/10):
The story starts in the near future after the events of the first season, while somewhat based on the latter's plot, it relies on an almost different cast, circulating around Akane of course, and so other familiar faces.
The threats are as strong as ever, ifnot more, the Sibyl system is more cornered that it ever was, lots of revolts and twist go along the way, will Akane keep up her hue unclouded? probably, you can only know if you watched the series ;)

The plot in this really tends to expand on the world and explain a lot of stuff we questioned in the first season, it also drives deep into the roots and foundations of the Sibyl system to make it clear to compare what has the Sibyl system come to, and where it began, the rigged nature only came later and turned it up the way it is now.


- Art(8.5/10):

Remember those crispy visuals? exactly, crazily reflect the nature of this show, the facial expressions are just so beautiful as they help the characters display a more emotional state second only to the voice acting, but have I told you how unattractive some of the CG scenes look? horrifying if that's a way to put it.


- Sound(8/10):

At first, I really looked down on this season's opening and ending sequences, but God does the production tea know its stuff, very classy music that sticks to the head easily, the suspect sound effects included.

The voice acting was great as always, with my personal English voice actor, “Christopher Sabat” in the party, (binge-watch goals).


- Character(7/10):

Unlike the first season, this one falls greatly in comparison, most of the characters are just dull, and their screentime doesn't help either, aside from few of our familiar faces, nobody really sets a remarkable act, including Akane herself, but the real disaster is the inspector “Mika”, ugh, so happy I would probably never hear from her again. the thing is, Kougami and especially Makishima set a really high ceiling on the first season, so it's the only natural for anybody else to fail at topping that.


- Enjoyment(7.5/10):

I did enjoy the watch, the twist was as crazy and messed up as ever, but I know for a fact that season 1 was hell a lot of a roller coaster, there were a lot of problems with this season, but it remains a decent sequel at least.


- Overall(7.7/10):

Ahh, how glad am I to live in a world that's nothing like this show, and what I'm more glad of, is I can finally convince somebody else to watch this great series, so that I can enjoy their reactions and point of views, totally a show to specify time for, grab some popcorn, get comfy and start a horrifying binge-watch, (no kids allowed).

Just as a heads up, there will be mild spoilers from the first season of Psycho-Pass in this review, so make sure you've seen that before reading this.
I'll be honest: it's just not the same without Ko. I miss him so very much. However, there are some moments where we get to see Akane think of him, and that was so damn beautiful.
Also, I wanted to see more of Gino. His character development in the previous season resulted in him becoming the coolest mofo next to Ko. Like... more of that, please.
I definitely preferred the Enforcers, story, and music from the first season, but oneof the things I preferred from this season was Akane. Hot damn, she was so badass. Easily one of my favorite female characters in anime. Again, she had astounding character development last season, and her new self definitely got the screen time it deserved without denying us of any more development (because, there is still character development to be had). \n\n
I think because this season was shorter, the story couldn't be fleshed out as much as the first season's, but I'm okay with that. It's often difficult for shows, books, movies, etc. to revamp themselves after a major storyline ends (like the storyline in the first season of Psycho-Pass). So, if this season were longer, it would feel unimportant and drawn out because it wasn't connected enough to the previous season/storyline.\n\n
Anyway, I think I'm done talking about this season for now. I still really enjoyed it. It didn't feel as "big picture" to me as the first season (because that was the primary storyline), but it was still a nice experience to sit down and watch. In some ways, it was almost nicer to be able to relax while watching it rather than being on the absolute edge of my seat the whole time like I was during the first season.\n\n
Well, I'm gonna watch the movie now. So, bye.

Psycho-Pass, the first season of the anime and the part that had basis in the manga was an absolute revelation into the world of Cyberpunk-esque, Dystopian Utopia and Totalitarian Authority that is so complex a difficulty to talk about and deal with even in forms of art.
Unfortunately, Season 2 felt like a shadow of the former season. Perhaps I had too much expectations of the show with the levels set as high 'Kogami and Makishima'. I have heard the argument of take everything for itself and without comparing it to something else but it does not apply here.  Not only because it is asequel but the cast, story and consequences are far too connected and that is how the show wants to.


Togane was obviously painted as a pseudo-Kogami but that works out for the better as his origins are revealed. He is the saving grace of the season along with the opening and ending themes of the show.

The antagonist, Kamui Kirito is almost tad too pretentious in all 'its' hybridized existence and the exasperation that I felt in giving a care about his journey, his truth and his easy-going ways. The way he dances around the society, tearing it apart just doesn't have gravity to the extent it should.

And Misako Oka-san is basically a wish fulfillment for all those who just wanted to see someone wipe away smug omniscient face of a haggard looking 'B' woman. She replaces Sibyl in form and is replaced by out by Kamui, who in turn sacrificing himself in a typical cop-out death that always follow a character with no future beyond a certain point.


Perhaps, the real disappointment is not seeing Tsunemori see no character development at; perhaps because that was because it was already set away in the season 1 storyline. But on the overall I was pleased with seeing the Enforcement squad with its unique members, Inspector Shimotsuki being not too unpleasant napkin of a character and the Professor being classic anime portrayal of a mystery man notwithstanding.


So to sum up, you'll nothing if you don't watch this. You may find some value in terms of the world lore if you do. I cannot tell how you will feel after watching it through but if you are fan and want to tick things off, It may as well be a pleasant experience.

Sequels often fail to capture the same light that their antecedents do; unless they are planned in advance, they are produced to satisfy fans and make more money, rather than filling out the particular world’s narrative. A particularly notable example would be The Heroes of Olympus by Rick Riordan. His first series, Percy Jackson and the Olympians, was nothing short of addicting Greek mythology primer as seen through a teen’s eyes. But his second series, while introducing the Roman counterparts and another camp for half-bloods, does not have the same feel. The writing is sub-par, the lingering awe for higher beings died, the main charactersare overpowered, and on and on.


Moreover, if a sequel follows the same basic storyline as the first, it is immediately criticized. I believe that lack of originality is not necessarily a cause for complaint, especially if the ripoff is good in and of itself (e.g. The Inheritance Cycle). Every new narrative is funded directly by inspiration from earlier works. This is not a bad thing.


Which brings me to a sequel, Psycho-Pass 2, whose antagonist is fairly similar to that of season one (S1) -- a criminally asymptomatic individual who escapes the scans of the Sibyl System. Yes, season two (S2) isn’t as good as the first in practically every respect. But it’s still an acute examination of the morally ambiguous consequences of a system powered by human brains that monitors every citizen’s potential to commit a crime. Although not as horrifying as S1, S2 still shocked me with some of the acts of evil and depravity, and the antagonist presented a needed response to Akane’s doubts of the Sibyl System. Akane remains clear no matter what happens, lucky her, while another character darkens the coefficient of others, and another clears the coefficient of others. Perhaps S2 was unnecessary, but I still enjoyed it. After all, with this premise, any serious threat to the Sibyl System would have to be a unique individual immune to it, which means an antagonist similar to Makishima. So get a grip, critics, let’s overlook the lack of complete and utter originality. Everything created is but a derivation of something that came before.


So if you liked S1 you should like S2 as well. Production I.G returns with a lucid yet gentle overlay of colors; the characters’ faces are perhaps too pale but that’s stylistic. The soundtrack is the same charged, driven orchestrals. And the moral dilemma called the Sibyl System is as strong as ever. The only thing I missed, really, was Kogami.

Sayonara!

A Review of Psycho-Pass 2:
Well, any show with the number 2 in the title is bound to not stray too far from the pre-existing ideas that are associated. Obviously there are exceptions to this way of thinking, but Psycho-Pass 2 is not one of them.
Set very soon after the conclusion of the first season, we see familiar faces doing what they've always done; upholding the law to the best of their ability. So, this show is VERY much like its predecessor, and it's a very good season on it's own, but I personally don't think it's as good as the one that came before. Onereason for this is the new characters. In the first season, we had 22 episodes to grow close to all the faces we saw interacting every episode. Now, half of those faces have been replaced and we only have 11 episodes to form any sort of bond with these new characters at all. They're not badly developed (save for one of the new Enforcers who gets hardly any screen time at all) and they're enjoyable, but they're not the same as the people we enjoyed watching in the first season.


Animation and sound are pretty much equivalent, though I do want to give special mention to one song that appeared in episode 9 during a very emotional scene. That was very well done.


The story...is confusing. I can see it as either being better or worse than the first season's main arc. This season, the story begins right from the get-go and is consistent throughout. it also feels like the perfect length for such a story. The first season took some time to get into and at times felt like it dragged on, so that's where I feel the second season is better. However, the second season isn't original. it simply builds on top of what the first season already laid out and threw in some small tidbits that were left out of the first season.


So, yeah, it's a pretty good sequel overall.


Positives:

+The theme song grew on me after a while. Not fantastic, but not awful

+Old characters appearing and acting like they always have

+The strong theme of morality

+Animation and sound are solid


Negatives:

-Opening theme took a while to grow on me

-New characters are meh

-Story simply builds off of previous season making it seem like a semi-rehash


I enjoyed the original Psycho-Pass and I definitely enjoyed the follow up to it. If the first season was just your cup of tea, you have no reason not to watch this.


That's why Psycho-Pass 2 gets a 9/10

This is technically a season 2 for Psycho Pass but it feels more like a sequel series instead. The story is pretty good with a whole new villain and a slightly different cast of secondary characters. The story sometimes appears even more fucked up than the last season while maintaining a similar level of blood and gore. Since the secret of the Sibyl system has already been revealed to the viewer the big mystery of the show is the goal of the main villain. This season is noticeably shorter because of it, which is a good thing because this plot would not have done aswell as it did if forced to stretch over 20 episodes.


The art is good, with cool technical designs and none of the character designs look terrible. They all manage to look unique while still managing to look normal for their society. The animation is smooth as the last season and never noticeably falters.


The music used in Psycho Pass 2 is just as good, if not better, than the music used in season 1. The voice actors for the new characters all manage to put on quality performances in the English dub. Sound effects are believable and well done.


If you aren't able to accept new characters easily you probably won't like this season because several major cast members from the last season don't show up. Instead several new characters are brought in that do a good job in their roles.

Tsunemori Akane - Once again the protagonist, this season tests her resolve to maintain the rule of Sibyl. She doesn't do a lot of character growth in this season but shows off a little of the growth she made at the end of the last. She maintains her character flaws as well though.

Kamui Kirito - The new 'villain' for this season, he is definitely a means justify the ends type of guy. He comes off as a lot nicer than the villain of the last season(and several side characters as well). Some viewers may be able to empathize with him though.

Tougane Sakuya - He starts off as an apparent replacement for Kougami but also grows into his own character. Whether or not you like him is up to you but I thought he was too much of a momma's boy.

Shimotsuki Mika - I think this character was designed for the viewer to hate. I was constantly hoping for character growth but disappointed. She was shown joining the force at the end of the last season but doesn't really grow in the year and a half between then and now. Something that I didn't notice even after rewatching is that she was involved in girls school case in the first season. She works as a character though, even if she isn't particularly likable.


Overall I enjoyed this season. I remember watching it every week on its initial release and it constantly kept me craving more. When marathoned its just as enjoyable though. I think it could even be watched without having seen the first season, though you might miss certain parts of the story. If you aren't big on 'changing of the guard' style cast transformation though this season might just piss you off. I do recommend though if you liked season 1.

SLIGHT spoilers, nothing major.
After watching this from taking so long since it had bad reviews, I can finally see why everyone hates it, and it's not for good reason. Season One followed the exact same formula as season two and even had a similar level of gore and shock factor, it was practically the same story - minus one character. 
I think the reason most people hate this season is because Kogami is gone. There, I said it. Everyone kind of got on their knees for him for some reason, but he didn't make OR break the show, he was merely a character there whobroke the rules a little. Was a season two necessary? Not really, but was it equally as good as season one? Yeah, since it's the same story just with another villain. The art style and animation was consistent just like season one, the team was as enjoyable to watch as season one (except for one SERIOUSLY annoying character), and Sibyl was just as corrupt as season one.


The only thing that I can see that would give people reason to hate on season two is actually Sibyl. The system had someone in the group who went against what Sibyl as a collective believed in but was SELECTED to run the case? Uh, ok. 


Overall, this is just as good as season one if you stop inserting yourself up Kogamis backside, it's enjoyable. 


Story - 6

Art - 10

Sound - 10

Character - 5

Enjoyment - 7

Overall - 8

Story (7/10)
I'm not even going to bother summarizing the story, because you have the synopsis right there when you click on the anime. But, I will tell you that I did enjoy the story, for the most part. I find it difficult to say that because it took me quite a while to get back into the story after episode 5 or 6. I think it's been roughly a year since I started Psycho-Pass 2. This is not to say that I didn't enjoy it overall, I did. I just found that the middle part of the plot got a bit rocky.
Art (7/10)
I'm no experton art style, nor do I claim to be, but I like the art style in this anime. The shading and colors add to the dark, almost surreal atmosphere. I really enjoy the contrast between the officers and the civilians. I might be imagining it, but I did notice a difference between the two and the former used darker, more menacing colors. I could be off the mark, though.


Sound (7/10)


As expected from Psycho-Pass, I thoroughly enjoyed the music they chose for the openings. I'm partial to the first season's opening, but that's just me. I even watched the last half or so of this show in the dubbed version. Disclaimer: I like both sub and dub, but it really depends on the anime and how I'm feeling. Sometimes I don't want to read subtitles.


Character (6/10)


I don't know about you, but personally I felt Akane was the only character (ironically, from how I felt about her in the first season) that I liked or felt any connection to at the end of it all. I feel like she developed well, and is a strong character compared to how she used to be. Otherwise, the others didn't leave much of an impression on me. I'm still not sure if that's good or bad. If the minor characters are too good, they take away from the main character, but that's the balance the writers have to find, I suppose.


Enjoyment (7/10)


I have a hard time giving the enjoyment more than a 7, because although I really liked the philosophy when I got back into Psycho-Pass 2, I didn't understand the ending that well, but maybe I missed something. If anyone wants to explain it to me in the comments I'd be glad to listen. For the sake of a spoiler-free review I'm trying not put a lot of plot in (or any, as I feel I'm doing right now) since my question is about the last episode. But anyway, I did enjoy the majority of Psycho-Pass 2, although I did think the ending to the first season was a whole lot more satisfying. I guess the problem I have with the ending is I don't feel fulfilled after finishing it, there's not crazy cliffhanger or sense of closure for me, it's more of an indifference.


Overall (7/10)


Overall, I would say that this is a good anime. I enjoyed the bits of philosophy that were peppered into it. Personally, I really like anime and stories that make me think and question things. This was well done and I would definitely recommend it if you want a bit of a sci-fi psychological thriller.

(Blanket warning for minor spoilers.)
What a shame - that's really all I can say at this point. 
The second installment of Psycho-Pass - the riveting 2012 series which had all the makings of an intelligent psychological thriller - is terrible. There's no two ways about that. Considering that Urobuchi is merely supervising the sequel and not writing it, like he did for the original, the cracks show. 
Being a sequel, Psycho-Pass 2 is susceptible to being compared to the original for obvious reasons and as such, it fails to deliver.
- SOUND (9/10): I enjoyed the OST used for the series and both the OP andED are pretty fantastic. The OST in particular is excellent, especially with the orchestral pieces used to enhance dramatic tension. It was fantastic in the first season and this has been carried over to the second, which works for me.


- ART (8/10): Akira Amano's character design definitely has a couple of flaws - anybody who's read Katekyo Hitman Reborn can confer the same face thing, but it's a stylistic issue and a personal gripe for the most part. What I liked here is the minor design changes to reflect the passing of time. Shame that only Gino and Akane received these and not the rest of the cast. I liked the backdrops too and it's fairly the same as to what I'd come to expect from from the first season, including the gory shots of blood and guts.


The problem for me was perhaps the usage of CGI and how it momentarily distracted me, but it was otherwise pretty good.


- STORY (4/10): And here's where Psycho-Pass 2 begins falling apart. 


The first season ends with the Sibyl System still in place and the initial problem still present. The second season deals with exactly the same problem as the first, but with about 200% less charisma and grace. Kamui's motives and his method of getting things done make absolutely no sense, Tougane starts off with obvious parallels to Kougami but falls flat at the end, and the less that is said about Mika's bumbling, the better. 


Probably the second biggest oversight - after the cast of characters - is how often the previously established rules of the Psycho-Pass world are ignored and dismissed and, worse, how incompetent the MWBPS appear to be this time around. Sure, it's explained away as the collective Sibyl System's problematic judgement, but so is everything else. Psycho-Pass 2 is successful in establishing the fact that the Sibyl System is not perfect, but that in itself doesn't make it interesting or compelling.


Another problem is the frequent use of gore. Too many people blown to bits this time around, to the point that it feels like it's being used as a shock factor. Psycho-Pass doesn't shy away from difficult to watch scenes - let's consider the first episode of the first season, for one - but there's no purpose to them here. Virtually half of the secondary cast is killed off messily and there's no real emotional impact to their deaths, neither on the other characters, nor on the audience.


And, finally, probably something less people comment on but - fanservice. Male-centric fanservice to be specific, with Shion, Kunizuka and the 2nd Division's Aoyanagi being stripped down to their underwear. I have no problem with it since it's not very distracting, but I wish that they'd levelled the playing field with some female-centric ones. I mean, we got shirtless Kougami in the first season; I could've done with more of that. :P


- CHARACTERS (3/10): The meat of any good psychological thriller is it's story, brought to life with compelling and well-developed characters. What a shame that we get neither the story nor the characters.


Akane is perhaps the most interesting out of all of the rest of the cast, which is not saying much. Her growth and position as a respected Inspector is a good watch, a far cry from who she was at the beginning of the first series. I liked the little detail with the cigarettes, a good way to exhibit her attachment to Kougami. 


The problem is that while Akane is a good character, the entire weight of the story is placed on her and the poor girl can't deliver while being exactly as pacifistic as she was the first time around. Akane needs a foil and for that we get three - Mika, Tougane and Kamui reprising the roles of Ginoza, Kougami and Makishima from the first season, and all of them fail at them utterly.


Kamui and Tougane's motives are lacklustre and they are explained via info dumps - something that automatically lessens their impact. Their development is non-existent and the chemistry between Tougane and Akane had potential, but it failed to deliver as such. Kamui's motives and actions have such laughable contradictions, and that's made even more annoying with Kamui being capable of doing nearly everything. Both Tougane and Kamui's methods of affecting a person's Psycho-Pass are explained, sure, but it's a hard swallow.


Let's not forget the side cast, which is mostly pushed aside. Shion and Kunizuka serve their minor roles to capacity, but the disappointment is the newer Enforcers, none of whom are given any room to grow. Explaining this away as the limitations of a shorter season is really no excuse - the show shouldn't introduce so many characters if it's not prepared to treat them right. Perhaps the biggest disappointment is Ginoza's treatment - he'd played an important secondary role in the first season, but he might as well not exist in the second. He's not used as well here and even though he gets his moments to shine, it's nowhere near enough development.


And, of course, the biggest beef I have with Psycho-Pass 2 - Shimotsuki Mika.


It's never explicitly stated at any point, but Mika played a role in the first season. She's nowhere near the same character though, and watching her bumble through the entire case is an exercise in frustration. 


For the record - I didn't like Akane initially. She's easily one of my top three characters in the Psycho-Pass 'verse now, given how we've watched her grow as a person. I was expecting the same from Mika but, sadly, that does not happen. 


The problems with Mika are numerous, but the one most obvious is her tendency to be snotty and high-handed, without actually having the talent to back it up. She talks back to her superior officer, undermines her decisions despite them showing results, ignores her Enforcer's advice and she can't handle situations effectively when actually placed at the helm (episode 4. Just... episode 4). All of this would be understandable if she were a fresh recruit but, nope, she's been working under Akane for a year and a half. 


Mika is more concerned with her Psycho-Pass than she is about doing anything useful. Her only shining moment comes when she cracks the Tougane secret, but even that proves to be a bust. She becomes an accomplice, indirectly causes the death of a citizen, but she chooses to never take any responsibility. She serves herself for the most part and isn't developed at all - no talk about her past, her family, her circumstances.  I couldn't empathize with her, because Mika blindly accepts everything about the Sibyl System, despite how fucked up it all is. Her conflict is non-existent and it only serves to prove that she's downright useless and incapable of utilizing her own agency. 


Yes, her story-line is basically how an average Sibyl-System-grown citizen would handle being in the same situation as Akane. However, that alone doesn't make it interesting and/or exciting to watch. Mika is frustrating from the start to the end and one can't even ignore her, because she's a part of the main cast. 


At least Makishima isn't completely ignored and is mentioned multiple times. The Kougami cameo was a nice touch, but I particularly enjoyed Akane-Jouji interactions and, well, Jouji in general. Perhaps one of the better things about Psycho-Pass 2 is that we get to watch Jouji work his magic.


OVERALL (4/10): Where the first season starts off slow then picks up momentum and ends on a high, the second does the same... except it all crashes and burns around the finale. Again, Kamui and Tougane were not compelling enough antagonists, the plot has holes, the characters are not developed well enough and then there's Mika. I imagine that the staff's intention was to make us feel sorry for her, but I couldn't do that with how much she frustrated me with her actions. I honestly wish there was a better character arc for her; it would've certainly elevated my enjoyment of the series a lot more.


Such a shame, because I really did want to like the second season. :(


To any enthusiasts of the original - just pretend that Season 1 is all that exists. The second certainly doesn't do well to live up to the first's legacy.

So far, this second season seems to be terrible... was expecting more from how season 1 ended. Actually, I feel that Psycho-Pass ended well in just season one and I am satisfied with the ending of the first season but the second season just doesn't seem to make me excited.
Story - 6
It's a continuation of season 1 with new characters added in the cast, no more Makishima and Kougami... however I am pretty disappointed because I don't find this that interesting as the first one. It's like they're repeating things that already happened and going " how could this be! " with things that havealready happened before in season 1. The villain's character isn't very exciting for me and I find some of the new characters irritating in general.


Art - 8

Pretty much the same as before but I think the first season really was better in terms of character design and the characters are not that bland-looking.. I don't mind the new one. The animation seems to be the same and not lacking in quality at least, and it keeps up with season one for the most part.  I wish the animation for the opening song was more interesting rather than clips being replayed, maybe I'm weird.


Sound - 8

Good. I think it still matches the story for the most part and they still have EGOIST, nice. 


Character - 5

Like I mentioned before, I felt that the new characters were irritating and I liked the season 1 characters more. Just not a fan of characters whining 24/7 and questioning everything. 


Enjoyment/Overall - 6

It seems terrible right now but I will finish this anime and decide for myself if this is worth it. I may rewatch the first season, I believe the story was perfect and didn't need a second season.

Psycho Pass season 2 packs quite a punch with tons of gore and extreme action sequences but it does lose a lot of its potent storytelling and character without Gen Urobuchi at the helm.  
The second season of Psycho Pass gets quite a mixed reaction amongst fans of the original and for good reason.  However, I still enjoyed my experience because of the amazing and twisted action sequences throughout the show.  I am a huge fan of horror anime and really gritty animation styles and I will say Psycho Pass season two delivered on this front.  After season one I neverimagined anything could compete with the brutality and twisted atmosphere of the original.  However, up against all odds, season 2 manages to be even more over the top with regards to action and suffering.  First off, the dominators are basically set to “blow it the fluff up” mode throughout the entire show as civilians, inspectors, and enforcers are all treated like bugs throughout the series.  Many of these fight sequences are well diversified as we encounter all out warfare involving bots, hostages, civilians, torture sequences, and villains alike.  These sequences were well paced throughout the show and worked well to hold your attention throughout the series as Psycho Pass has established itself as a show that never holds back on the gore.  The choreography and animation also provides a ton of suspense throughout the show and added a level of intensity to the series as you can feel every character movement during the action sequences.  The sci fi elements were also strong in season 2 as the shots of the city along with the technology the characters use throughout the show also held my attention.  All of these themes and aspects combined into a very fast paced and intense horror action experience.


Psycho Pass may be tons of fun for horror fans but season 2 does have a few drawbacks most notably with regards to the characters and writing.  Gen Urobuchi is a master story teller who wrote many interesting and meaningful conversations between characters during season 1 which added a lot of meaning and development to complement the horror themes of the first season.  This elevated the first season as these conversations where extremely philosophical and intriguing.  However, these meaningful conversations along with character development is absent in season 2.  This can be attributed to the 12 episode format which leaves less time to develop characters with the amount of action sequences that are already present in the show.  The characters from season 1 that appear are still in character.  For example, Tsunami is still very smart and quick to solving problems.  However, other newer characters leave a lot to be desired.  The villain Kamui is basically a lesser version of Shogo.  Shimotsuki is a one note character whose only trait is being naïve, and Tougane’s intentions were too obvious to warrant suspense or interest during the show.  Overall, when it comes to characters, season 2 is a mixed bag with more misses than hits.


The story also struggles to be at the level of season 1 as it’s simply a copy paste rehash of season 1 with less suspense or creativity.  There is not much to say about it because you have already seen it and the new writers don’t even try to hide it as from the beginning we are immediately introduced to Kamui and the troubles he causes the Sibyl system.  From there it is a condensed 11 episode version of season 1 with nothing to add to the series.  This rehashed story line only serves as a baseline for the Sci Fi action sequences throughout the show.


Psycho Pass season 2 is a still a fun time because of the insane exploitative sequences of Sci Fi action complemented by some outstanding animation even if it is lacking in depth and character.  If you like horror action you should watch season 2 of Psycho Pass but if you are looking for something more from an anime you may be underwhelmed.

I'm going to be completely honest here & just get right to the point. This is supposed to be a continuation from the previous season & that I honestly think it isn't that bad as other people make it out to be but it isn't really good either.
Story was actually simple to understand what was going on in Season 2 yet that's the problem where Season 2 suffers. The Writing is more easily to understand what was happening throughout Season 2 in other words this Type of Direction is completely Average. It isn't that Complex nor that Fleshed out as the previous season. An AverageJoe like me was capable enough to understand Season 2 so easily that I find it somewhat insulting because Season 1 had time Fleshing the Story out & being Complex for a viewer like me to slowly understand what was going on. 


Mika, a side character, was handled so poorly out of the other characters. She came off as an Annoying Know-it-all and disrespected Akane. She is the only character that I despised throughout Season 2.


As for the Antagonist he was handled fine but he wasn't that interesting nor that investing in my perspective.


I actually think Season 2 was Average at Best, there are some things I like while other things I didn't like. People say "Don't watch it, it's not worth it" for me I would say give it a chance just to have your own opinion but watch at least 3 to 5 episodes to see if it's worth watching.

This continuation just has too much of a convoluted and messy story to really stand at the same ground as the first season. 
Starting right where we left of, the story is centered around Akane, and returning as well as new members of Division 1, trying to apply justice in the distopian Japan where Sybil reigns as it avaluates a persons capability of becoming a latent criminal. This time around, we have our antagonist, Kamui, who wants to prove that the sistem is not perfect, and confronts the Public Safety Bureau, with his various schemes, all while we progressively learn various plot points about Sybil,and the vthe diverse cast. The problem is the repetition of the main arch plot, all this has been done... the diference is that there's a much more focused approach, and with a reduced number of episodes it doesn't allow for much world or character building. 5/10 Story


The art is fenomenal, it's really gripping to watch all the effects, since there are so many contrasts of colors, and the dark tone, relating to the type of story and world we are settled in. Overall this and the sound are the best aspect of this second season. 8/10 Art


The characters are another problem, especially Kamui, first he is introduced as a poor man's Makishima, but as the story unfolds, he develops a lot more, and his backstory and goals help in that matter, but they are not as solid as Makishima's. Akane is the only real character who has a development and personality, maturing since the first season and dealing with the various problems she encounters. But the missing part is that there isn't really any strong connection between her and the antagonist, any real tension between morals like Makishima and Kogami and even her in S1. And the rest of Division 1 is really a miss, since they are not as developed, only Tougane and while promissing, his integration in the story isn't that good. 5/10 Characters


It started well enough, and you can say it is extremely well paced, it was gripping, but the problems emerging were to many that, while good to stand on it's own, doesn't really compare to the brilliant first season, not progressing in any way in its conclusion, serving as a good action oriented sci fi, with a confusing plot embedded.

I have to begin this review by saying that albeit I'm giving it a full score, it is by no means perfect. It has many flaws. That said, there is an explanation for such contradiction and it is my own, personal method of evaluation. To me, if the pros in a work of fiction are big enough they negate the cons. And PP2 has spectacular highs. In fact, I consider the first season closer to perfection than this second, but this second season has much, much higher highs than the first season. It's just unfortunate that the lows are also lower.
STORY
The story is good enough,very tense and at many points clever. It also never ceased to surprise me with its twists and turns. And the cliffhangers at the end of the episodes, ah the cliffhangers! It relies and feeds back much more into the mythology of Psycho-Pass than the first season, being much more sci-fi and much more investigative. But then there are the flaws. It's very bad at explaining some points in some parts, making it harder than it should to understand in an apparent way of trying to make some points more clever than they really are. Also, some characters are sidelined, like Ginoza, for example, that was an important character in the first season and now is just an extra in the background most of the time. But there is a positive side in the characters department too. Akane is AWESOME in this second season, finally worthy of being the main character, she's smart and brave and cunning. She's badass. And there is another female character that people will hate, and she is a good addition. Also the nemy is pretty much Makishima Shougo but only much improved. Makishima was good on paper but lacking in execution, and Kamui is a bigger threat and brings forth more interesting developments about Sybil.\n\n
ART AND SOUND\n
I'm putting them together because there is nothing much to say than that they're incredible. I'm not very good at judging animation, I think. I can't really see fails other people see, so take my judgement with a grain of salt. But the sound desing is good too, enhancing a perfectly paced, perfectly tense mood.\n\n
VERDICT\n
It's much better than the first season (but don't jump to it, it depends on the first season). And Psycho-Pass 2 also, in its final episode, gives a hint to future developments, but it's too open if a third season doesn't come to be. So I would recommend it. To everyone, I think its subject matter probably interests anyone. Some set pieces astound and the revelations, albeit I admit a bit silly at times, always manage to make sense. It's just good.

Psycho-Pass 2 - Great sequel to the original series. Definitely not as bad as some people make it out to be but it was a tough act to follow. Felt like a logical progression in the story of the Sibyl System.
Loved - The parallelism between making someone clear and making someone black. First season focused on criminally asymptomatic people and making people black. Exploration of making some one clear and where it went with the Sybil system was a much needed breath of fresh air. Also that ending theme song.
Disliked - The opening themes video was bland, obvious spoilers in it. Season felt a littlerushed, might have done better with a few more episodes to flesh out the 'villain', how he was actually clearing people. Secondary characters weren't fleshed out.


Should you watch Psycho-Pass 2?


Absolutely. Don't believe the haters.


8.5/10

I'll be generous and give this a 7 out of 10.
I have mixed feelings about this season. I really wanted to like it. As a heavy Psycho Pass fan, I really wanted to enjoy a return to this show. I ended up being disappointed with many aspects of this show.
Many of the show's problems can be attributed to its main villain, Kamui.
I'm not going to go to any spoilers, but the best way to describe him would be that he's a ghost. From what the previous show's villain, Makishima Shougo, left, Kamui has quite the big shoes to fill. Unfortunately, he fails for the mostpart to be as interesting as Makishima.


1) Makishima always had this air about him that despite being a genius, he was beatable. This allowed for an interesting cat and mouse chase between him and the inspectors. Kamui doesn't have any of that. He comes off as invincible and too good even by the own shows standards. He has too many people following him, too many resources, and winds up pulling too many gambits to the point that it can leave the viewer very confused.


2) The problem with Kamui is that he's clearly a villain that's forced by the writers to become more dangerous than he has any right to be all for the sake of being a bigger threat than the series' previous antagonist. He winds up pulling feats that just seem too much or too far fetched in a world that is governed by CCTV cameras everywhere. 


3) While he performed great feats, Makishima was human, while Kamui is a ghost. Which I'm guessing is what the writers were going for. However, they failed to portray this properly and execute their idea in a way that the audience can accept. Despite his interesting concept, his background story sounds ridiculous and he winds up being too much.


4) Kamui feels like a copy and paste version of Makishima. Despite the differing concepts of the two antagonist, they are very much alike. Instead of going for another villain with a new personality contrasting his predecessor, we are ultimately left with a guy who tries too hard to beat the other and it shows.


Although, I will say that Kamui does pull off feats that genuinely left me impressed. His portrayal and execution in the long run did not leave me with a good lasting impression on him.


I watched the movie, and so far I could skip this entire season without getting too lost there. Although there are some pivotal moments in this show, they are not enough to warrant watching a full season of boring explanation after boring explanation just to catch up. Nothing overall has been changed. If you're that interested, watch it. Otherwise, stay clear.

I haven’t watched a lot of current anime so I figured with the finale of Psycho-Pass 2 having come out this week it’s as good a time as any to play a bit of catch-up and check out the series that have been getting praise this past year. Psycho-Pass is a good start as the first season is one of my favorite anime ever and this second season has been rather divisive among fans and critics, meaning it’s time for me to formulate an opinion.
The first season of Psycho-Pass was written by Gen Urobuchi and was a mix between cyberpunk and a dystopian future, somethingthat worked really well and produced a unique world and story (my two favorite types of science fiction). The show had issues with being too pretentious and other, smaller parts that took away from the overall story, but for the most part it was an excellent, enjoyable ride.


The second season is getting a lot of unjust flak for a lot of things I feel the show did right. This season has issues but, truth be told, I marathoned the entire show this evening and couldn’t have had a more enjoyable time.


In this season a bad guy with the ability to bypass the Sybil system by not having a crime co-efficient nor a hue (the color corresponding to the state of a person’s psyche) is leading Akane and the freshly recruited inspector Shimotsuki across Tokyo in a bid to stop his madness. Along the way the man begins collecting Dominators, the weapons that the agents use to stop or kill criminals after gauging their psycho-pass, and experiments with how to use them.


I thought the plot was tense, multi-layered, and worked out really well. It pushed the anime toward an existential crisis type ending that these sort of anime tend to have while also allowing enough action and intrigue to keep someone not as involved in the philosophy from falling asleep.


One issue comes from the fact that Gen Urobuchi isn’t the writer. While the story is good, the writing can be pretty bad at times and I was especially cringing at the first episode. Thankfully, that first episode is not an indication of what to expect further along and the writing got mildly better, though never as good as Gen.


Another problem of this series is that we’re introduced to a load of new characters who don’t get a lot of time to develop, probably the biggest problem for most people. And this is an understandable gripe as the first season had a decently developed team of characters. But that season was twice the length of this one and I think the focus on a very well-paced story works to the advantage here.


I won’t get into the characters who’ve joined Akane’s team as none of them are worth discussing. The main characterization here is the fact Akane is now senior to a newbie who does things a way that doesn’t exactly work in the society she belongs to. The duo are at odds throughout the entire show and later on, as Shimotsuki learns about what the Sibyl system is and starts into a sort of mental breakdown, we see the only true character development the series manages.


The animation is at times superb, at others it relies heavily on awkward looking CG. The music ranges from the bad opening to pretty good tracks during the show, to a decent ending.


As Psycho-Pass 2 is only about three and a half hours in length (subtracting the opening and closings) there’s not a lot I can say about it, especially without spoiling things. It’s missing some key elements that made the original so enticing but is still an intelligent and interesting romp through a unique world. It’s gruesome, it’s violent, it’s thoughtful, and it comes together to a mildly satisfactory conclusion.


All in all, Psycho-Pass 2 is a worthy follow up. It’s not as good as its predecessor, nor is it all that particularly bad. It’s a short, intelligent crime drama that, while not as memorable as the first season, is still pretty solid nonetheless

The second season of Psycho Pass is downright awful. End of story.
I'd upload a decent analytical review, explaining why it is so horrible, but neither do I have the time, nor do I feel like putting in more effort than the actual writers did.
Awful recycled, messy, if not plainly nonsensical plot with some of the greatest asspulls since Mirai Nikki plus pointless lines of dialogues and characters whose creation ended with their design.
We're talking about writers here that literally tried to give a definitive answer to the omnipotence paradox. And in one or two sentences at that.
Just stay away if you want to keep theoverall positive experience of season one because pretty much everything that made it good left the building for this season.

Hey folks, this will be my review for a steaming pile of... wait I mean Psycho-Pass 2. Its easy to get those two things confused. Pyscho-Pass 2 takes everything that was good about the first series and removes it, doubles the amount of annoying characters and installs more illogical arguments and situations and serves it up in a much more manageable size of 11 episodes. Lets begin the review and hopefully validate this terrible score.
First the story takes place a short time after the events of the first series. Akane is now head inspector, a few enforcers are gone for various reasons and a newdetective joins the group. The story begins much the same way as the first season, an event occurs but it seems to be the work of some master criminal pulling the strings from the background. Akane and gang then go on an investigation to figure out who it could possibly be. Of course during the investigation they forget some of the events of the first season and ask silly questions like is it possible to fool the sybil system? We also have new information given to us or rather crammed in to the show in order to try and patch up some of the story holes.


The story picks up towards the middle again, as though it needs the extra speed to kill itself with the last few episodes. Plots within plots and failed logic abound as everyone's favorite detective comes to the rescue of justice. Does justice prevail? Well that's up to you to find out. There were a few interesting conversations towards the end but really the simple fact that its over is its saving grace. 


Now lets talk about the characters a little. Akane is only slightly annoying in this season though I'm sure this is again do to the choice to mask her poor character behind a more annoying character (Mika Shimotsuki) who is seemingly trying to win backstabbing cunt of the year award. The enforcers have little significance this time around and the only one worth a mention is the new enforcer (Sakuya Tougane) who plays a seemingly intricate part in the muddled story. The other characters only got a short scene here or there to show that they still are alive and to make it seem perfectly normal that every character is a master criminal, world level hacker, super charismatic leader, tireless bad ass and a telepath. Again there are a few interesting interactions and my hopes got raised towards the end of the show as some interesting developments arise for Mika, but sadly they were quickly let down.


Art and sound again were very well done. Cant have any complaints here. 


My enjoyment of the show was not existent. I wanted to finish it so I didn't have to restart it in the future. The show takes itself to seriously to behave in the manner that it did. This time it doesn't even matter about whether or not you agree with the terms of "justice". This season was bad because it felt like it was written for children to say "Wow this is deep" as they pretend to their friends that they understood it and try to gain some level of cool or maturity from their lies. Luckily I had no emotional attachment to the show so I was able to just steamroll through the episodes in only minor frustration and unfortunate boredom.


TLDR: Did you watch the first season? Do you have plans to watch the first season? If yes then watch this and be disappointed. If no, then stay the hell away.

*tl;dr at the bottom of the page
After finishing a solid season one of Psycho Pass, I found out that there was a second season and I couldn't ignore it. I wanted to review the two seasons of Psycho Pass together, but after watching the second season it became clear that the quality of the anime significantly worsened. That is why I will review the two seasons of Psycho Pass separately, and now on to the review. 
The second season of Psycho Pass occurs eighteen months after the first season. We meet new character additions to division 1 of the MWPSB and a new antagonist seekingto confront the Sibyl System. 


The plot of Psycho Pass 2, especially the second half of the anime, is quite disappointing. The first half of the anime gives a sense of suspense and anticipation of what will happen next that really made me sit on the edge of my seat. It really hooked me in and I couldn't stop watching. The second half, however, made me scratch my head multiple times in confusion. The build up for the main antagonist Kamui was really well done, but the build up fails to deliver at the end as the anime hits a giant brick wall. The plot holes are inconsistent with the characters and the story and simply make little to no sense at times. Oh the plot twists, don't even get me started on those. 


Continuing from its first season, the animation is great. It is the best part of Psycho Pass 2 and the saving grace of it. I could have easily given this anime a 4 or 5 instead of a 6 if it was not for its animation. The anime uses darker colors especially well to reflect its dark atmosphere and the dark atmosphere effectively set the tone for it. The music is the kind you would expect in a psychological and sci-fi anime, but nothing extremely special. The ending song is my personal favorite for this anime and I enjoy the osts quite a bit as well. 


And here we get to the characters, oh boy do I have a lot to say. I can write a whole essay alone just by ranting on about my least favorite character, the new inspector in division 1, Shimotsuki, aka the "relentless bitch". So relentless bitch is an extremely despicable character who believes that she is always right and refuses to listen or hear from others. She looks down on enforcers and even her fellow investigator Akane as well. Not only that, she is also extremely weak and indecisive to the point of making you want to flip tables and never gets anything done. Did she even fire a single shot this whole season? And then we have the new enforcers as well. Hinakawa and Tougane. Hinakawa is an expect on holograms and is shy, not a whole lot to say about him. Tougane is a strong enforcer that resembles Kougami from season one. Tougane had the most potential out of all the new characters, but the anime fails to effectively develop him as a character.


Then we have the new antagonist Kamui. While some people say that he is basically the same as Makishima from season one, I give him a little more credit. The anime does show how far Kamui is willing to go to achieve his goals, and he does some things that Makishima would probably never do. However, his goal is extremely similar to that of Makishima and he basically drives season two into another "freedom vs order" argument. 


Finally we have the original characters from season one. I was quite frustrated with how they treated Ginoza and Kougami. Ginoza becomes a complete side character despite the huge influence and development he had in season one. Kougami doesn't even make a physical appearance in season two, just what the fuck. They spent so much time on Ginoza and Kougami in season one just to completely throw them off to the side in season two that I question how they came to that decision in the first place. Akane actually does get good development as it shows her new role as the senior investigator of division 1 and the effects of her decision to accept the sibyl system for the time being. She is the one breath of fresh air among all the other characters in this anime. 


I did not enjoy the second season of Psycho Pass as much as I did the first season. It is not good sequel to the solid first season and only drags this series down as a whole. And god, I still can't get relentless bitch Shimotsuki off my mind. 


"Enough you Idiot! Shorten it to 20 words or less!" -Saitama (One Punch Man)

(tl;dr) PP2 started off great and had some potential with its plot and characters, but fails to deliver at the end.

I think this anime is underrated. The story is original and it really gives a lot to think about.
There are some parts that remind me of Ghost in the Shell and others of Tokyo Ghoul but in resemblance and not as in a copycat. I think this is something positive since the ones who enjoyed those anime can have another one to enjoy.
I loved the first season and the development of the main character but the second was even better.
There were many unexpected turns, of behavior and plot. 
I thought of it as thrilling and intriguing.
I also loved the main character, Akane's physical design thatis a bit contrary to her personality. She is a short cute girl that seems to be naive at first and can easily be underestimated but she has a strong and honest personality that makes her a real role model and a true leader.\n\n

Warning possible Spoilers
Despite only being half the length of the first series I still think the second series actually put up a good effort to make a sequel to this brilliant franchise.
The story continues with Akane Tsunemori who has learnt about the secrets of Sibyl and has vowed not to reveal their secrets so she carries on to uphold justice until a new threat changes everything.
Now I have to applaud the story once again especially considering this was only 11 episodes and despite the length it was still very entertaining, it had some interesting plot twists like the last season although some things were predictable.
Itwas very interesting seeing Akane being pushed even further than before as she has become the leader of Unit 1 and is desperately trying to keep her convictions intact from this new threat that is trying to threaten the authority of the Sibyl system considering she knows it's secrets.

Once again there is more loss in this series that puts Akane even more on edge and makes her very desperate not to get clouded from the actions affecting her and that even the people she is working with can't be trusted as they too pose a threat to her investigation.


The characters mostly consist of characters from season 1 excluding Kougami and some others who died, but the characters that replaced them weren't exactly up to snuff.

Akane continues to be the badass she was at the end of series 1 and this series really tested her abilities as a leader and person and the fact she made it through all that happened really shows how much of a resolved person she is.

The people that survived series 1 didn't really get as much screentime compared to the first series and their characters aren't really expanded upon however Ginoza has now become an enforcer which makes him see his teammates from a new perspective since he is now one of them, but his character isn't really expanded upon any further.

The new characters were certainly mixed in my opinion, Sakuya Tougane who is a new member is a very seclusive person and has the highest coefficient on record although he does believe in Akane's belief, but his reveal as a villain didn't surprise me at all since he looked suspicious anyway.

Mika Shimotsuki was actually a student in the first series and has now become an inspector, but she is annoying as hell she doesn't even trust Akane's judgement or actions and the fact she kept on whining about it didn't help whatsoever for her character.

Kirito Kamui is the new villain of this season and despite not being as good as Shougo he was still pretty interesting because the fact he couldn't be detected b Dominators was interesting enough and finding out why he couldn't be detected sounded pretty grim and shows why he wanted to reveal the secrets of the Sibyl system.


The artstyle remained as well done to the first series and didn't really have nothing really new to add other than making peoples deaths even more gruesome than the last series like when there was a massacre a bank or when Kirito transplanted someones eye so he could use it himself.


The action was a bit more variance to the first series like how drones were hacked in and used to kill the workers and enforcement officers by cleverly being disguised as a video game making people not realise that they were killing people on purpose.


The psychological aspect was again done very well too as it shows the difficult situations Akane had to go through without her mind being clouded which made her look like a heart less human being, but you realise she is hurting on the inside and that she must focus on the job first and let loose later.


Overall I feel like this series shouldn't really get the slack it got because despite not being as good in some areas compared to the first series it certainly kept other areas at a good enough level to make this worth watching.

As a person that loved Ragnarock, Busorenkin, Robotech, Death note and not to mention Hellsing and even Ergo Proxy, i must say this one is a good story crepe like strait out of Steven king, og Hitchcock.
The suddel ideals that you can create the perfect society by implementing system that monitors your psych. is scary, its like Flin said in Tron, the idea that you can create something that is flawless is an ungraspable ideal like Icarus thinking he could reach the sun with a pair of wax glued wings on his back. 
If I was to paraphrase it, it would say its like theold anekdote that the way to make frog sup is by putting the frog in cold water and then heating it up gradually the frog would not realise his impending doom before it was already to late but if you where to put him in hot water he would jump out strait away.\n\n

Firstly, I should say that I haven't got a free-time to spend to watch the 1st season, so this review purely, solely, dedicated and discuss for the 2nd season only, Psycho-Pass 2 (サイコパス2). Aired on Fall 2014 along w/ other awesome anime series didn't let Psycho-Pass 2 down. It stands along w/ Akame ga Kill!, Donten ni Warau, Akatsuki no Yona, Amagi Brilliant Park, Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works, Gugure! Kokkuri-san, and Kiseijuu. What so damn tough opponents those are!
    The story centers around the heroine, Akane Tsunemori and her division to capture the rebel against Sybil System, named Kamui. It's complicatedand every episode makes you curious about what will going on next and what's behind the motive of this Kamui to questioned the system which rules society. By this summary, I hope it won't bring spoiler at all wwww~

Eventho' the storyline sounds simple but the conflict both intrapersonal and interpersonal of each characters runs deeper than you imagine. If I could say it's so philosophical and meaningful. Even w/ such a hard topic to bring with, the delivery of every questions to solve the case go on so smooth yet mysterious. That's how I like this series the most.


    Another boost point is also the music. Ling tosite Sigure with "Enigmatic Feeling" as opening and EGOIST with "Fallen", are the blast. The rhythm, tempo, as well as gloomy lyrics bring an unspeakable excitement which feels so fit w/ the series.


    As my words deliver the information about the improvement of each characters above, I shouldn't say much about it~maybe it will ruin the viewers feel who haven't watched it to enjoy the series. According to what my acquaintance said, there are few new characters added in this second season, compared to the first season, the new characters here really goes boom the story and conflicts.



For such the great plot and other aspects of it, I give 9 for the series ♪

Pros:

Great plot and somewhat mysterious stuffs

Damn catchy theme songs


Cons:

The improvement of the case seems to overreact by make it so dramatic
